(c) the avenues of redress that may be open to a client who considers that a bank is in breach of its fiduciary obligations;
(d) whether any current or recent practices by banks may be viewed as contravening their fiduciary duties to clients; and
(e) the extent of any such practices and the action that should be taken by the Government to prevent them and compensate those adversely affected by them.
Legal and Constitutional Affairs

To translate this motion into layman's terms, it simply proposes that, in the interests of the average Australian, there now be a general inquiry into the manner in which banks are conducting themselves in Australia today. This is not a new proposal; it is a proposal which I have been addressing conscientiously in this chamber for almost 15 months. It is only a slight variation on a specific proposition which I put to the Senate in April and which was defeated by the combined vote of the Government and the Opposition.

The long and the short of it is that we are saying that it is time for a cold, detached and objective look at what is happening in Australian banking today. We do not pretend for one moment that the Subcommittee of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs will have either the time or the resources to undertake the in-depth examination that we believe is justified, but we sense that this is the most appropriate first step.

I believe that this reference to the Committee is simply to establish whether there is a prima facie case for a more comprehensive inquiry into banking in Australia today. I am sure that the Senate is aware that there has not been such a comprehensive inquiry into banking in Australia since the 1930s. I am sure that the Senate is aware that the focus of this inquiry is the fundamental fiduciary relationship which exists in law between a bank and its client. In layman's terms a `fiduciary relationship' means that there is an obligation upon a bank to consider the interests of its client equal to that of its own.

Historically and traditionally, there are those who would have said that Australians could have had confidence that their banks were pursuing their interests as vigorously as they were pursuing their own. However, since deregulation of the banking system in this country-and deregulation occurred in 1984-85-we believe that there is clear evidence that the whole ethos of banking has changed dramatically and has swung in favour of the banks and that the banks are exploiting this new climate in a greedy manner which is unprecedented in Australia's history and which makes them the world's greediest banks. Those who are disadvantaged by this new ethos of banking are the average Australian and the average Australian family.

As I say, this proposition for such an investigation was placed before the Senate by me in April and defeated then by the combined vote of the Government and the Opposition. So I suppose the question can reasonably be posed: why bring it back? Has the situation changed in six months? I believe it has changed quite dramatically. There has been an enormous shift in public opinion about banking in this country in the six months since this proposition was discussed in April. I do not believe that a single senator or Federal parliamentarian can deny that. It has in fact been acknowledged in the other place by Government members in recent weeks. It has been the subject of some considerable debate within Government ranks in recent weeks. In fact, the Government was on the verge of having such an inquiry, but it backed away from an inquiry for reasons I will discuss in greater detail shortly.

Why has there been a build-up of animosity within the Australian community about banking? Certainly a good deal of media attention has been attracted to banking in the last six to eight months. Today we shall hear the argument advanced by both the Government and the Opposition that this theme is purely and simply a populist theme promoted by the Australian Democrats, specifically by me, in order to capture some pre-election interest. They are right, of course: It is absolutely vital that this matter be brought before the Australian public in a pre-election context. It is absolutely vital that the Government be made to face the issue in the few months before an election. It is absolutely vital that the Opposition be called upon to state its position on this crucial matter. If `populist' means an acknowledgment of the fact that in the community there are people who have a burning concern about this issue, it is a populist issue. They are the sorts of issues which should be precisely those that are being addressed vigorously, conscientiously and with genuine intention, by parliamentarians in the period immediately prior to an election. So if that is the definition of `populist', this is indeed a very populist issue.

But there is more to it than that. It has been said that we are into bank bashing. What is bank bashing? If it means being critical of the greediest banking system in the world, then we are into bank bashing. If it means acknowledging that the banking system has abandoned the interests of its clients in pursuit of its own profits, then okay, we are into bank bashing. Indeed, the banks are bashing Australians out of business and out of their homes. I believe it is genuine retaliation. It is an appeal, through the only means available to them-an appeal to their elected representatives. It is a response from genuinely exploited, persecuted and downgraded average Australians and their families to a banking system which is running riot in this deregulated state.

There is also a growing awareness of the degree of greed being displayed by banks. It is an extraordinary degree of greed, which I will elaborate on in a moment. There is a growing awareness that banks are enjoying what they themselves call super profits. There is an interest in how they arrive at these super profits. I think there is a return to an examination of the very nature of banking. We are all aware that during the 1920s and 1930s, during the period of the social credit movement or Douglas credit, there was a burning concern in communities about the very nature and the power of banks.

Look at just how powerful, in the crudest basic way, these institutions are. In the first place, they have the power to create credit or money. Credit is the positive side of the entry that goes into the ledger. To extend credit to a client is a nice positive sounding phrase. But what the banks are actually doing is extending a debt to a client; they are inviting a client to enter into a substantial debt. So the first power of the banks is to create credit or to create debt in the community. They have created massive debt in our community; the debts of ordinary Australians, the debts of families and the debts of businesses are substantially created deliberately by banks.

The second aspect of banking is that the debt then has to be serviced in the form of interest payments. If we are talking about a mortgage, the interest payment is from 17 running through to possibly 18 per cent. One might be lucky, if one borrowed a few years ago, to have an interest rate held at 13 1/2 per cent. So one services one's mortgage, overdraft, personal loan and every debt through interest payments of a magnitude probably somewhere between 18 per cent and 30 per cent. These are absolutely undreamt of levels of interest rates. Ten years ago it would have been inconceivable that we would now be servicing this vast national debt at these levels of interest-basically with the interests of only the banks at heart.

The third aspect-this is the most devastating power of the banks-is that if people cannot continue to service that debt, as many Australians now cannot, the banks can move to foreclose on them, taking their homes, businesses, assets and the lot. I was sent a tape the other day with the title I want the earth plus 5%. It is about the attitude today of the greedy banks in Australia and internationally.

There is a growing awareness that banks are all-powerful. There is also a growing awareness that they are running riot and bleeding us white. That awareness expresses itself in the form of foreclosure on assets. I had a conversation with a farmer about five minutes before I came into this chamber this morning. He was saying, basically, `Can't you do anything because I am going to lose the farm this week?'. There are literally thousands of Australian primary producers in such a position. So there is a growing awareness and a growing concern about this extraordinary power of the banks.

Of course, deregulation was supposed to make banking more competitive. If you and I, Madam Acting Deputy President, were competing in the market-place we would normally do so by offering our services at reduced price. The banks have not done that. They behave like a cartel even though that is prohibited under the Trade Practices Act. Although they will deny it, this group of people, through deliberate collusion, actually puts its prices up. If we watch the behaviour of the banks we can suspect only that there is a cartel operating because, if one puts up its charges or its rate of interest, sometimes within hours and certainly within days not only will competing banks, their competitors, do the same thing but so, subsequently, will building societies, credit unions and virtually all other financiers in this country. That is cartel-like behaviour even though the banks will deny it.

The fact is that the ethos of banking in a deregulated banking system has dramatically changed and essentially it is about profit making. Is there any evidence that this profiteering is running riot? Let us look at the profits of banks in just the last 15 to 18 months. In the last financial year all major banks in Australia announced record profits. They called them, in their own terms, `super profits'. In a confidential memo, the manager of finance in the National Australia Bank Ltd, Mr Argus, expressed embarrassment about these super profits and said, `Under no circumstances must certain information be made available in the context of these embarrassingly high profits'. But that was last financial year. We have now seen the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, the people's bank, announce an increase in profits of 74 per cent. That was in the same fortnight that it put out its hand to take a portion of the $200m subsidy from the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to make it appear as though it was keeping down its mortgage rate and really holding the interest of Australian families first and foremost. So the banks took $200m in taxpayers' money from the same people who were being leached by interest rates in the first place. That happened in the same month that the Managing Director of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia was reappointed at a salary of $250,000 a year-a 100 per cent increase in salary. This is the ethos of banking in Australia in the late 1980s and early 1990s. This is the deregulated, out of control, profiteering, greedy banking ethos that we are confronted with in Australia today.

I refer to the Argus memo which I have tabled in the Senate. It revealed not only the super profits in the banking industry, and the embarrassment thereof, but also other things which were happening in the banking industry. Above all, my point is that it is irrefutable that the fundamental fiduciary relationship between banker and client has been dramatically changed and eroded under deregulated banking. This matter requires investigation. Such an investigation is included in the terms of reference of the motion which I have put before the Senate today. The banks have enormous dimensions of greed. We ask ourselves: How are they making the super profits? They make them by operating at profit margins which are twice the level that is acceptable to international banks in Switzerland and other similar banks overseas. In other words, Australia's banks are copping it easy, to a point where they are laughing at us. They are operating at profit margins which are twice the level of those which are considered to be economically acceptable to similar banks in other Western economies.

In relation to bank charges, we really do not know what banks are charging us. Hopefully, very soon it will be obligatory for banks to state their range of charges and their rates. I will refer to some examples. We know that banks actually charge people to operate small accounts. There was a time when the banks paid to attract such deposits, but now the banks charge people for making small deposits and holding small accounts. I refer to some extraordinary examples of the ethos of bank charging. One example of a miscellaneous bank charge-and that is what it is shown as on most bank statements-was for an amount of $28,000 that appeared on a corporate account fairly recently. Admittedly it was a huge account, but that was the amount of the miscellaneous bank charge. When it was queried, the bank said, `Sorry, it is a mistake, forget it'. So the company was told to forget a $28,000 mistake. If the bank had got away with it, it would have a beautiful windfall, would it not?

A businessman in Tasmania with whom I spoke recently operates three business accounts at the same branch. He has queried the last 35 miscellaneous bank charges on those three accounts. They have all been withdrawn because the bank could not explain them or justify them. A woman in Tasmania thought she had made arrangements for an account in Melbourne to be transferred to a Hobart branch. The bank said that the arrangements would be made. She went ahead and drew eight cheques, none of which was for more than $40. They were all bounced and there was a $25 fee for each of the eight bounced cheques. Does that suggest that the banks are considering the interests of their clients as being equal to their own?

Another example is that of a pensioner who was charged $15 for forgetting to put his signature on a cheque. It would have cost the bank 41c to advise him of the error by mail, or less by phone, but it charged him $15. Is that an example of banks considering the interests of a client as being equal to their own? Another extraordinary example is that of a gentleman who pursued the matter of bank fees for two years. He said, `Tell me what these fees are'. Eventually he received a letter from his bank, after two years, which said, `If you persist in asking us about these fees we will send the matter to our lawyer and the legal fee will be charged to your account without redress'. Is that an example of the fiduciary relationship? It is an example of how banks see that relationship today.

One of the most pathetic of all examples is the one that was quoted in the local press 10 or 12 months ago. A young child went into the local branch of a bank with a piggy bank, it was opened and counted, and the child was charged 10 per cent of the contents of that piggy bank for the process of opening and counting it. Is this an example of the ethos of banking in Australia today? It does not matter whether we are talking about $28,000 mistakes in miscellaneous bank charges or a child's piggy bank. It is all an expression of exactly the same mentality and attitude in banking in Australia today.

The great concern in the community today is interest rates because that is where it hurts most. Who knows what interest people are paying to banks? Most people do not know. The Argus memo which I referred to earlier-the confidential memo from the finance manager of the National Australia Bank to his State managers-revealed that he did not know what interest rates were charged on overdrafts. It was a memo about the discrepancies between loadings that were put on overdrafts. It revealed the fact that the National Australia Bank branch managers put a loading varying between about 2 per cent and almost 10 per cent on top of the base rate of 18.25 per cent. The Argus memo said, `We didn't know this. We are now telling you and we are telling you it's bad news because it projects a bad image, particularly in the light of these embarrassingly high super profits. Above all, we must make sure that this does not get out and about because it is bad for our image'. What image? The image of the fiduciary relationship? Of course it was bad for it. The long and the short of it is that most of us do not know what interest rates we are paying to banks at any time.

We can all cast our minds back to our primary school education when we first started to do interest calculations. We needed to know three things to find out how much interest was paid. We needed to know the amount on which it was being paid, the rate at which it was being paid and the period over which it was being paid. Most of us do not know any of those three things about the interest we are paying to our banks. We pick up our bank statement and it says, `Bank interest-X number of dollars'. Interest at what rate, on what sum and over what period? We do not know. The bank never tells us. The bank could not give a damn. It just writes a figure in. The realities are that the banks are running riot and the Government knows it. That is why the chairman of the relevant committee in the other place recommended an inquiry. The Opposition knows it but it is not going to acknowledge it. The community knows it. It knows that the banks are running riot and enjoying super profits but it would prefer to address the technical questions of banking-the interface between the management of the economy and the banks-all of which are very serious, challenging and relevant questions but they are not the questions I am posing. The question I am posing is not the relationship between banks and this economy or the world economy but the interface between banks and ordinary everyday Australians. The nature of that relationship as it is stated in law is what we are asking to be investigated.

I have not even touched on the matters of allegations of malpractice and corruption which I have brought into this place week after week and the parallel allegations of neglected duty by the Australian Federal Police in investigating those matters. I have not even mentioned those issues at this stage. That is another vast area which has to be investigated if we are really going to look at what is happening in banking in Australia today.

What have been the reactions to the suggestion of an inquiry into banking? The Australian Bankers Association says that an inquiry is not necessary, that I am exaggerating, that there is no corruption in banking and that banking is squeaky clean. That is about as credible as my saying that there is no corruption in politics or the police saying that there is no corruption in the police force. It is a farcical response. It is a ludicrous response to what clearly are justifiable concerns within the community. The banks accuse me of not doing my homework. I have done thousands of hours of homework in relation to the issue. They accuse me of not providing any evidence. I have come here week after week tabling the evidence of what is happening out there. The media have reacted. They believe that there is a real issue in banking in Australia and they have been pursuing it, albeit often at their own legal peril, for the last few months.

The community is aware of the fact that there is a problem out there. That is why it is getting behind me and forming a Bankwatch in Perth, Adelaide, Leeton, Albury, Nowra, Sydney and Brisbane. We are forming groups called Bankwatch to insist that the process of examination continue. Even local governments are now aware of the problem. They have written me a letter expressing support for the concept of an investigation. I have a letter from the Conargo Shire Council over the signature of the Shire Clerk, which passes on to me a number of recent resolutions of that Council supporting an investigation. The second resolution says:

RESOLVED . . . [to] support action investigated by Senator P McLean (Democrat), Mr S Martin, MP (Labor) and Mr R. Price, MP (Labor) calling for an inquiry into finance and banking; that additionally, Council support moves for an independent Committee to be set up to investigate the role of banking and finance in Australia and that Council indicate the intent of both this motion and motion no. 179 to Senator McLean, Mr Martin, MP, and Mr Price, MP.

Of course, two of those people were interested for a couple of weeks but, as soon as the pressure came on from within the ranks of government to back off the issue, all of a sudden I was left in splendid isolation as the one proposing a bank inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —That could be your fate in life, I'm afraid.

—I thank Senator Stone. It could well be my fate in life and it is one that I am prepared to pursue. Why has the Government reacted in the way it has? Its backbenchers have said, `For heaven's sake, do you realise what is out there in the community about banking?'. That has been the cry. Then, of course, there was the possibility of the Government actually creating an inquiry. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) said, `Good grief, do we really want this? Do we really want to expose the realities of a deregulated banking system?'. He said, `I am the architect of this deregulated system. I am the one who has been singing its praises and putting the final pieces in place'-through legislation that passed through this Senate two days ago. He said, `This is the model which is supported by the Opposition and which will remain in place in Australian banking possibly for decades. Do we really want the truth about this investigated and revealed? The Government backbenchers backed away as quickly as a snap of the fingers. There is not enough moral courage in the Parliament to take on the banks. It is as simple as that. The banks are the most powerful institutions in the land and there is grave reluctance to challenge them about their ethos, their modus operandi, their profiteering and their exploitation.

SPEECH.PARA: So there was a reversal. For about 10 days we had a possibility of a bank inquiry on our hands. Panic broke out among the banks and then finally in the Treasury and within the Caucus, and the Government backed off. The Opposition's reaction has been superficial. The last time the matter was debated in this chamber it said that a lot of the cases were sub judice and that we could not interfere with the processes of law. The majority of them are not sub judice. The reality is that there will always be some disputes between a client and a bank before the courts. Of course, one does not interfere in cases which are sub judice, but there is a lot more which one should investigate and interfere with which are not sub judice.

Today we will hear the populist argument trotted out by both the Government and the Opposition. Of course, this is a populist cause. It is populist causes which should be addressed by the Government and by the alternative government. The fact that the Australian Democrats are the only ones who are prepared to make it a populist cause, and pursue it as such, is something of which we are proud. If the Government wants to base its redress on that, and respond at that level, it is politically naive.

In summary, what we are really doing is continuing to blow up a storm. As I say at every public meeting I address on this and other issues, politicians-all of us-are fickle. That is the nature of politics. We have to respond to storms and winds. That is what democracy is-people blowing up storms and their representatives responding. Perhaps we have to blow up a huge storm about banking so that eventually a government which has got enough moral courage, short term or long term-or an alternative government which has got enough moral courage-will bend to the wind and begin the process of returning to sanity and justice by setting up an inquiry, albeit relatively briefly, to establish a prima facie case and recommend to the Parliament a suitable structure to investigate, and reveal to Australians, that the fiduciary capacity of banks to truly pursue the interests of Australians has long since collapsed, and that something desperately needs to be done about it. That is the intent of this motion. I wait anxiously to hear the response from the Government which accepts this at heart.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator McLean, your time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McLean has unashamedly said in this Senate that he is pursuing a populist cause. There is no need for us to denigrate the idea that elected representatives of the people try to bring to the attention of a chamber such as the Senate a matter of great concern to many people. No doubt there are grave misgivings among members of the community-some more explicit than others-and maybe it is true that there is a general unease about the way in which banking and financial institutions are conducting themselves, which generates considerable profits for their shareholders to whom they also have a duty.

SPEECH.PARA: It is easy to see why those who fall foul of a particular branch manager over a particular transaction gather together in meetings, such as those which Senator McLean addresses, and call for an inquiry of some sort into the banking industry. My distaste for Senator McLean's performance here today is not so much because he is trying to represent those Australians who feel hurt in some way by the actions of the banking sector, but because he holds out a false hope in his motion which he has brought to the Senate today. The expectations that he thereby arouses cannot be fulfilled, as one can see from looking through the terms of his motion. He is being extremely cruel and heartless in pretending that he can come into this chamber and, if he got this motion passed by the Senate, would resolve the hurt and undo the damage that some people may consider they have suffered at the hands of their bankers. It is for holding out that false hope that I condemn Senator McLean who, on this issue, has become an obsessive figure.

I notice he came up again with a charge against the Australian Federal Police that members have been involved in some sort of cover-up in relation to the matters which he has brought to the attention of the Senate. I have explained to the Senate on several occasions how all the matters tabled by Senator McLean have been considered quite properly by the Federal Police in the only way open to them, that is, to consider whether any criminal charges might be properly laid as a result of the information which he has tabled; and the Federal Police have said that there are no such cases.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator McLean is obsessed with getting re-elected.

—I think that is his current obsession. I have repudiated and rebutted here in the Senate his allegation against the Federal Police, whom he has virtually accused over many months of engaging in some sort of grand conspiracy, particularly with Don Sanders, the esteemed Managing Director of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, in a way which has led us, he would claim, to a cover-up of serious criminal activity, because it is only serious criminal activity-breaches of Federal laws-that the Federal Police can properly investigate. Indeed, as he would now surely concede, most of the matters that he raises are matters to be dealt with in the civil jurisdiction of appropriate courts. I will come to that in a moment.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator McLean continues with this baseless allegation, this repudiated allegation. But that is only a side issue; it is not actually part of his motion. His motion is not concerned with criminal charges; it is concerned with fiduciary duty. I will speak about that in a moment. It is the false hope that he holds out to these many hundreds of Australians-perhaps to a wider group of Australians, numbering tens or hundreds of thousands-who feel some hurt and who have misgivings that I find most objectionable. One immediate indication of the false hope is that Senator McLean, in putting this motion to refer certain matters to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, asks it to conduct an inquiry and report on or before the first day of sitting in 1990. In other words, he is saying to the Australian people that the Senate Committee can undertake this huge inquiry, which it would be, consider and deliberate and produce a report by the first sitting day of 1990.

Everyone in the Senate chamber who knows the tremendous load being undertaken by that Committee under the distinguished chairmanship of Senator Barney Cooney of Victoria would know that that is quite unreasonable. It could never possibly be achieved. I have had a look at the list; there are five or six major inquiries being undertaken, including the cost of legal services and litigation in Australia today. That is a huge inquiry in itself which we know will consume the attention and the resources of that Committee for many, many months-well into the next calendar year. Yet Senator McLean, in his populist way-he says that that term has a certain political dignity, and I will concede that for a moment-says that he can organise a Senate committee to discharge its responsibilities in a considered and proper way by the first sitting day of 1990 in relation to his proposed limited inquiry into certain aspects of the way the banking industry relates to individual clients. It is utterly unable to be achieved; it is a false hope. Senator McLean is to be condemned really for that alone. People will not find quick answers presented by a Senate committee by the due reporting date that he suggests.
The other matter concerning false hope is this: part (e) of this motion states that the Committee should require and report on:
the extent of any such practices-
that is, practices which contravene fiduciary duties-
and the action that should be taken by the Government to prevent them and compensate those adversely affected by them.

Senator McLean is holding out the hope that the Committee will recommend to the Government that those who have been adversely affected by a breach of fiduciary duty should be compensated. He must know, as every honourable senator must know, that there is no way in which the Senate Committee can award compensation; there is no way in which it can direct that compensation to be paid. The most it could do, if it were appropriate-I will argue that in a moment-in particular cases brought to its attention would be to suggest some payment, though on what basis I do not know. If there is a breach of fiduciary duty between a bank and a client, quite clearly the duty to pay compensation or damages, as it is more properly known, would rest on the bank. For the taxpayers of Australia to bear some cost in settling the result of that breach of fiduciary duty would be quite extraordinary.

Senator McLean is going out to these hustings and to these public meetings and saying to people who are concerned or to individuals who write to him or who call on him in his many thousands of hours of homework that he undertakes obsessively on this issue, `Look, I am going to set up a Senate committee and if it finds that you have been adversely dealt with by the bank in breach of its fiduciary duty'-which somehow the committee will determine-`I will make sure that that committee gets you some compensation from the taxpayers of Australia'. That is an extraordinary proposition and one which I think is completely unfair and cruel to the people concerned because, once again, it is a hope that cannot be fulfilled. The committee can merely recommend and indicate whether it is appropriate. Of course, it is utterly inappropriate that that should occur. That is part of the false hope that Senator McLean is holding out and which makes the term `populist' have the sort of colouring and the degenerate political qualities that are usually associated with it.

Were I to have been prepared to accept the term `populist' earlier in good faith as merely representing a storm of public opinion, when we get to the stage that Senator McLean has reached on those two issues alone-the reporting date and holding out the hope of compensation-I now say populism, in the more traditionally adverse sense of the word, is properly applied to Senator McLean. I do not like to make these debates personal but I believe that Senator McLean is misleading people in a grievous manner which will hurt them.

I will just ask a little more about how this committee will operate. The term `compensation' is spoken about. Senator McLean's motion talks about compensating those adversely affected by breaches of fiduciary duty. Compensation is a term which we more commonly think of in terms of damages; that is, a way of assessing the real impact, the real hurt and the real economic disadvantage which has been suffered by a person as a result of the breach of fiduciary duty. It has to be measured in some way. It has to be established that there has been a breach of fiduciary duty and then there has to be a measurement of the damages.

Senator McLean is apparently expecting that people will-as they must because of the way in which he is generating false hopes-come before the committee and state their case. Somehow the committee will have to act in the role of a court and make a determination as to whether there has been a breach of fiduciary duty and whether compensation might be awarded. That is not a proper role for a Senate committee. Senator McLean said, `I brought this up in April; I am bringing it up again because great things have happened in the last six months'. He did not mention two things which have happened in the last six months. One is the decision by the banking sector to set up the office of banking ombudsman. I will elaborate on that in a moment. In the half hour allocated to him, Senator McLean did not mention-I wonder whether he mentions it when he goes to various public meetings around Australia-that the office of banking ombudsman has been established. I wonder also whether he has mentioned that in the last several weeks there have been very interesting decisions by the Federal Court of Australia indicating how banks owe fiduciary duty to their clients, for example, particularly in relation to the Swiss francs business which has been one of the catalysts for the concerns in the community.

I am sure that Senator McLean will have a clipping of all matters relating to banking but he did not appear to bring this one into the chamber. I read an article in the 2-3 September issue of the Weekend Australian that stated:
A company developer yesterday successfully rejected a claim by Westpac Banking Corporation that he pay about $800,000 losses incurred when the Australian dollar fell against the Swiss franc in 1985.

In the second foreign currency loan case Westpac has lost this year in the Federal Court, Justice Foster yesterday in Sydney found Mr Barry Lee, then manager of the Liverpool and Castlereagh streets branch of the bank had been negligent when he told Mr Charles Henry Spice there was `no catch' in an off-shore loan.
Justice Foster found that the bank, through its officers, was in breach of the common law duty of care and their conduct was misleading or deceptive under the Trade Practices Act.
He ordered the bank to accept $800,000 in full settlement.

In other words, many of the matters which Senator McLean raised earlier this year concerning those sorts of foreign currency loans have been addressed in the proper forum: the court. The court has made its findings on the facts but in relation to the law which it has further explained and clarified in its relation to this question of Swiss franc loan losses. Of course, there will be cases where claims are dismissed by the court. In fact, a report in today's Age states:
A Melbourne businessman who lost $336,510 in a loan in Swiss francs yesterday lost a claim against the National Australia Bank in the Supreme Court.
The article continues:
Mr Justice Tadgell dismissed all the claims, ruling that the bank had discharged its duty to warn of the risks in a foreign currency loan.
But is not that the proper forum? Is that not the way in which these matters should be investigated?

There is another forum in which some claims might be properly looked at. The banking ombudsman may provide that forum. Senator McLean studiously avoided mentioning this innovation which, once again, will be found in any file that he might have compiled in his office in relation to banking matters. For example, if one picks up the Australian Financial Review of 24 October this year, one finds the following under the heading `Bank ombudsman to decide on what's fair' by Richard Brass:
Banks will be liable for claims of up to $100,000 from aggrieved consumers under the terms of reference of the banking industry ombudsman scheme, released yesterday.
Does Senator McLean have that release? Has he examined it? The article continues:

Funded by the banks themselves and modelled largely on the British bank ombudsman system, the scheme will provide for disputed claims of up to $100,000 to be dealt with by the ombudsman if the dispute-settling procedures of the bank involved fail to produce an agreement with the consumer.

We know that a council will be set up with three of its members being drawn from consumer organisations and three from the banking industry. I must pay a particular tribute to my colleague Senator Bolkus, the Minister for Consumer Affairs, for his role in ensuring that consumer organisations which represent clients of the banking industry might have a place on this council. Of course, the council is to be chaired by the former Governor-General, Sir Ninian Stephen. I hope that I do not hear from Senator McLean any suggestion that a council under such eminent chairmanship as that of the former Governor-General, Sir Ninian Stephen, will be anything other than independent and of great integrity. The council will be able to use its powers in a way which will help alleviate some situations. It will be able to investigate and resolve a dispute in a way which may not necessitate the full paraphernalia of a court hearing.

I believe that, if Senator McLean looks at what has happened in the last six months since he moved a motion of this type, he will see that there has been considerable movement and considerable response in appropriate ways, in terms of the Federal Court, the Supreme Courts around Australia and the setting up of the office of banking ombudsman, to the sorts of concerns which undoubtedly exist out in the community. But I believe that to come into this chamber yet again and to move a motion which holds out very false hope for those who may feel aggrieved or adversely affected by a decision of their banker or who may be the subject of some relationship that has gone sour is very cruel and very heartless. This chamber should play no part in fostering Senator McLean's particular obsession.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose to speak briefly to this motion. Six months ago Senator McLean, as he has reminded us, came into this chamber and took up the time of the Senate, as he is doing today, by putting forward a motion not totally dissimilar from the present one which called upon the Senate to institute a committee of inquiry into the banking system and, in particular, into certain matters in the banking area to which at that time he was attaching particular importance. At that time the Australian Democrats were expecting, as most of us were, an election to be called in July or August of this year. Undoubtedly an election would have been called at that time but for the fact that, following the change in leadership in the coalition parties, the Government found that it was no longer convenient and that Mr Keating's great game plan was no longer operating quite as smoothly as he had hoped. Therefore, that election had to be postponed; it has recently again been postponed. An election is now scheduled for the early part of next year and Senator McLean is moving his pre-election motion to refer these banking matters to a Senate committee.

SPEECH.PARA: On the last occasion, he chose a Senate select committee-I hope I am correct in saying that-but on this occasion he has chosen the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. I confess an interest in that respect because I happen to be a member of that Committee. The Chairman of the Committee, Senator Barney Cooney, is in the chamber. I am sure that if Senator Cooney were to speak on the matter he would confirm my view-indeed, the view just stated by the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate)-that the sheer hollowness of the motion from Senator McLean is nowhere better illustrated than in the very idea that the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs could conceivably conduct an inquiry of the breadth and magnitude put forward in Senator McLean's motion within the ambit of the time period laid down in the motion, namely, that it be completed before the first day of sitting in 1990. That is just over two months away, with the Christmas period intervening. Senator McLean may be prepared to commit the staff of the Senate to working throughout their Christmas break; I am not prepared to treat people in that way, even if the Australian Democrats are so prepared for their own political purposes.

Since last April when we debated this matter, nothing has changed. I qualify that statement in one degree, picking up as I do one or two of the comments made by the Minister. One or two things have changed. In particular, we have seen a number of court decisions in some of the areas that were the subject of Senator McLean's originally expressed concerns. I will not bore the chamber by repeating the decisions which were quoted by the Minister, although, as he pointed out, one decision illustrated that not all of Senator McLean's concerns apparently are shared by the courts of the land. That is as we would expect because quite clearly there have been varying experiences in this area, as has been said in the past. There have been experiences where quite clearly banks have been lacking in the full discharge of their fiduciary duties to their clients. There is no question about that. Some bank managers have been; others have not. That is what we would expect. In the web of life we find that some people are competent and others are incompetent. The toy politicians on my left are in the latter category and among bank managers there is an admixture of the two.

As Senator Tate quite rightly said, this is a shameful attempt by the Australian Democrats to exploit the unhappy personal circumstances facing many Australians today as a result of this Government's policies. That is not quite the way the Minister put the point, but it is true that a number of people today are in great distress as a result of very high and prolonged interest rates, as well as for other reasons. Senator McLean put a lot of stress upon the result of deregulation. We do not have time to debate that question today, other than to say that, as usual, it is a subject on which the Australian Democrats' knowledge could be put on the head of a pin. What we have today is a motion which sets out to shoot the messenger. The situation in the monetary banking area today is 99 per cent the result of government policies and one per cent the result of the actions of particular individuals in the banking system. But, lo and behold, the Australian Democrats once again want to shoot the messenger! The fact is that if-I stress the word `if'-any inquiry into these matters were to be appropriate, it would not be an inquiry to be carried out by a Senate select committee or standing committee. We have made that point before. It would be an inquiry carried out by a properly constituted royal commission with independent and properly appointed experts in the field-not by a bunch of politicians including, God forbid, some toy politician from the Australian Democrats.

As a matter of fact, we have had a couple of committees of inquiry of that kind in the last decade. In case Senator McLean has not heard of it, I remind him of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System in 1981-82. Hot on the heels of that Committee, just after the Government came to office, we had the Martin Review of the Australian Financial System which had the narrower job basically of looking into the recommendations of the Campbell Committee and giving a second opinion on them. This junk stuff contained in the motion before us today, as Senator McLean was partially honest enough to admit, is no more and no less than a piece of cheap populism designed to promote the electoral fortunes of the Australian Democrats.

I do not want to waste the time of the Senate any more than it has been wasted already this morning by debating the motion further. However, I do want to pick up one of Senator McLean's more extraordinary comments in advancing the reasons that we should be considering this proposal. He said that the banks have the power to create debt and are creating debts all over the place. He is saying that it is all the banks' fault that people are in debt; that the banks created the debt. I do not know where Senator McLean spends his time. I have a small mortgage. My bank did not create that debt. I went to live in Queensland and became a member of this place, somewhat to my cost. As a consequence of moving my abode I wanted to buy a house in Queensland. I could not quite afford to do so, so I went to my bank and said, `Will you lend me the necessary balance?'.

According to Senator McLean's exposition of the way these things go, the bank created that debt. I created the debt by going to the bank and asking it to lend me money. If Senator McLean cannot understand the distinction he should not be participating in a debate on such matters. However, I quickly correct myself by saying that this debate is not about banking; it is not about any of the matters which are ponderously and pompously set out in the motion before the chamber; it is about the Australian Democrats wanting to get a reference to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs so they can get the television cameras in showing Senator McLean putting forward all this populist stuff that he has picked up. He told us that it is filed in cabinets six feet high in his room. I have no doubt that it is because, as the Minister pointed out, he has become quite obsessive about this matter. However, I do not see why the Australian Parliament should have to waste its time dealing with Senator McLean's obsessions or, even less, the political future of the Australian Democrats.

In recent times on ABC radio the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Janine Haines, has appealed to Australians not to desert the Australian Democrats. For years the Democrats have scurried around like the proverbial political jackals that they are, trying to pick up every bit of decaying carcass of public issue that is in sight. Every time some ex-Liberal Party, ex-Labor Party or ex-National Party voter gets a bit disgruntled with the party of his original preference and wonders what he can do to punish it, the Australian Democrats come along and say, `Vote for us. We don't stand for anything. We have no policies. We simply put forward whatever you want to hear. Then we go down the street and tell the other fella something which is 180 degrees opposite to what we have told you, but he does not know about the conversation we have had with you'.

That has been the practice of the Australian Democrats ever since their party was formed. One has to say that, on the whole, they have parleyed that into a rather successful operation of a minor kind over the years, but unfortunately for the Democrats-and this is their real problem-the Green Independents and others, who are now contending for other kinds of populist issues, are giving them some competition. It now looks as if the Australian Democrats will be in real trouble at the next election in getting any of their short term senators re-elected. I can only devoutly trust that that will be the case. As a result they are whipping themselves into a frenzy by putting forward in this place, as we see to our cost every day, more and more populist motions on this or that. Whenever they think they can spy a dissatisfied clientele-irrespective of whether it is three of four voters in the country-they will bring forward a motion and send out press releases hoping to get the attention of people who are utterly dissatisfied about this or that, so that they can ride forward on their white chargers and go to their rescue.

All I can say to Senator McLean and his colleagues is that this kind of shoddy, shabby corruption of a political debate will not work. I believe that the Australian people are not quite so stupid as the Australian Democrats clearly think they are. They will not have the wool pulled over their eyes by this continual parade of good intentions-of course, the intentions are different with every group-on the part of the Democrats. I will not dignify the motion by continuing to debate it in this place. Australia faces a national crisis and yet the Democrats bring forward this sort of stuff. Last week they talked about putting a tax on bank promotional advertising or some other thing that at that time they thought might gain them a vote or two. The Opposition opposes the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-In layman's terms, the proposition before the Senate is to ask one of the Senate's standing committees to decide whether or not we have a problem in banking in Australia; if so, what should be done about it; and specifically to provide an answer to the question: `Are average Australians being disadvantaged by the way in which banks conduct their business in the community?'. It is a fairly simple proposition. It may well be that after relatively short deliberations the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs will come back and say, `We sure have a problem. It is a big one and it needs to be addressed in a certain way', perhaps by a royal commission or some other mechanism. Both Senator Tate and Senator Stone have made a big thing of the fact that the enormity of the challenge is such that it renders it impossible. It may well be that the enormity of the challenge simply means that the Committee comes back very quickly and says that we need to put in place a highly resourced royal commission which can probe the magnitude and dimensions of this question.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Tate started off by saying that I have come to the rescue of a few people who have, to use an expression, `fallen foul of the banks'. Obviously he was not registering the point I was making, that is, that most Australians are dissatisfied with banks. If `falling foul' means incurring unacceptable levels of interest, resenting undisclosed and unknown levels of charging, all Australians have fallen foul of their banking system. That is why there is such a high level of resentment in the community. Senator Tate, in a very weak response to a profound issue, attempted to suggest that it was all about a handful of people who had fallen foul of the banks and had disputes that should be resolved in the courts. Of course some of those disputes can be resolved in the courts. However, most of the people I am talking about can never pursue their dispute with a bank in the courts. They are broken financially, emotionally and maritally. They cannot match the unlimited resources of banks or the banks' access to the best legal minds.

To say that these few people who have fallen foul of the banks, should pursue their cause in the courts is to fly in the face of what the realities are. That is exactly what Senator Tate has done as the Minister for Justice in this land. He turned his back today on the realities regarding some aspects of justice. He accused me of creating false hope. What hope did I create? I created the hope that a standing committee of this Parliament might be prepared to look at one of the most serious social issues in Australia today-and Senator Tate calls it a false hope!

TALK.START.PARA: —God help us all if that is the case.

—Yes, God help us all if that is the case. Can we have no hope in our Senate and in our Ministers? To be told that I am creating false hope and that I am cruel in pursuing the interests of Australian families is just a superficial, spurious response to a profound question.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister quite reasonably responded to allegations that have been directed at the Australian Federal Police. I have not directed those allegations; they have been directed by Australian constituents. I have brought them into the chamber and I have put them before the responsible Minister, who resents the fact that I have done so and has chosen to see it as some sort of insult. I saw it as some sort of obligation to bring such allegations into the chamber. However, the Minister chose to be offended by the allegations. That level of reaction is not adequate. The Minister and Senator Stone both made a big issue of the fact that the courts are available as a mode of resolving problems of justice in this country. The courts are available, but access to them on these issues is available to relatively few people. If one gets there it is usually after a number of years. It is usually after enormous expense. It requires a particularly persistent, courageous, well-resourced, determined and well-informed person even to begin that process.

I have tabled the case of a gentleman from Newcastle who had to take on the State Bank of New South Wales, which claimed to be the Crown and therefore exempt from the Trade Practices Act. He had to take that issue to the High Court of Australia to win a technical point in order to go back into the Supreme Court of New South Wales to try to get damages from the bank. Very few people have the moral courage or the resources to get that sort of act together. I believe that the Minister for Justice should be concerned about the fact that ordinary Australians do not have access to the courts. Most of those people cannot get access to legal aid.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is why there is an inquiry on.
—That is why we need a parallel inquiry.
—You are trying to disrupt that inquiry.

—I hope that the inquiry produces for the Minister the reality about who can and who cannot get legal aid in this country to pursue issues such as this. I have confidence that the Committee, which is chaired by Senator Barney Cooney, will reveal some of those realities and that the Minister will take them into account and not throw back the argument that we can all just run into courts to resolve our disputes.
—When are you going to come on to the ombudsman?
—I am coming on to the ombudsman right now but before I do I would like to refer to the Minister's arguments about compensation. He chose to deliberately misinterpret this motion.
—Madam Acting Deputy President, I ask that the very offensive imputation that I chose to deliberately misinterpret or misread Senator McLean's motion be withdrawn.
—Senator McLean, you should withdraw.

—I withdraw, Madam Acting Deputy President. There was no offence meant. My point was that the intention of the motion was misrepresented, perhaps unintentionally. We were not suggesting that the taxpayer be the compensator, or that the taxpayer meet the bill for damages. That, of course, would be unrealistic. It is a ridiculous suggestion. It is not a suggestion. The suggestion is that the Committee observe and comment on the means by which people might be compensated.

SPEECH.PARA: I will come to the question of the ombudsman, because it is very important. I was aware of the fact that I had more time available to me. I have asked to be the first person to appear before the Australia Bank Council and to appear before the ombudsman. I have had a tentative reply from Sir Ninian Stephen in response to that request. I think most honourable senators will be aware of the fact that it is partly-and it has been acknowledged in the press as being so-in response to what I have been doing in the Senate over the last 15 months that the Australia Bank Council has been formed and that an ombudsman is about to be employed by that Bank Council who will be responsible to it. The role of the bank ombudsman is a model that is pursued overseas with some effect and with some limitations. The Jack report in Britain made observations about the role of the bank ombudsman in Britain. It is suggested that it is not unreasonable to see the bank ombudsman as perhaps the bank looking at banks, and many people find that unacceptable-as unacceptable as the police looking at the police.

The concept of a bank ombudsman has lots going for it but it also has its limitations. I concede the fact that the Australia Bank Council seems to be very credibly structured at this stage, but it has not actually met yet to the best of my knowledge. I am not prepared to give it bouquets in advance because it happens to have reputable people on it. I am not disputing that. Nor am I prepared to give it bouquets in advance because it is chaired by an eminent Australian. We have to wait and see how the Bank Council, the ombudsman and the chairperson perform in this new role. The Council has to establish its credentials by performance. I have asked to appear before it, as I have said, and I will table before it the 50 affidavits-I will probably have 60 or 70 affidavits by then-that I have tabled in the Senate. I will put them on the table before the ombudsman. I will push them across the table and say, `There is your first year's work'. The reality is that I have been the de facto ombudsman for the last 12 months. That information will go across the desk. I know that a lot of it will come back because the terms of reference are such that it will not be appropriate for many of the complaints I have been addressing in the Senate to go before the ombudsman.

The very fact that there is a limit of $100,000 compensation from the banks for disputants makes it a petty cash league of redress. Many of the cases which I have tabled in affidavits before the Senate involve sums well in excess of $100,000. Very few of them involve less than $100,000. In other words, a person would have to go before the ombudsman, perhaps win compensation for $100,000, then pursue the balance of it-and in some cases it is millions of dollars-back in the court of law. There will be, in fact, an appearance of justice having occurred and a process of redress being available. It may well be just a preliminary process of redress which will sap the energy, the commitment and the expectations of these individuals for a relatively limited outcome. I have some reservations about it, but I am prepared to take it on good faith. However, I will not make the judgment in advance, as the Minister is doing here this morning, that all will now be well because we have a bank ombudsman.

TALK.START.PARA: —At least you are now mentioning it.

—I had intended to mention it all the way along. I knew that I had the good fortune of having the extra time available. So let us not pretend that the concept of a bank ombudsman will resolve all of our problems about banking. It will not. In fact it can even be argued that it is a pretty fair old operation, as far as the banks are concerned, to contribute between the four major banks which have made massive profits of billions of dollars. Do honourable senators know that the banks will put up $2m to fund this process, they will write it off against their tax, and they will save millions of dollars in legal fees by enticing people to go before an alternative process and the lawyers will just rip millions of dollars out of the banks? It could be seen to be a jolly good financial operation as far as the banks are concerned because it has an extra pay-off; it has a public relations dimension to it.

SPEECH.PARA: All of a sudden the banks have responded to all these allegations about their bad image and they have created a process which deals with petty cash claims, which saves them taxes and legal fees and which will probably deal with only a handful of cases in a year anyway. I am not as confident about this process of the bank ombudsman as the Minister for Justice is. The Jack report in Britain was not as confident or as praising of the process of the bank ombudsman; in fact, it said that it was very much a case of banks looking at banks.

TALK.START.PARA: —Different terms of reference.

—Different terms of reference, yes; I am just speaking in general terms. But in Britain it is very much a case of banks looking at banks and about petty issues of disputes. So it may well be that the bank ombudsman is a part of the answer.

SPEECH.PARA: From my discussions with the responsible Minister, the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus), I agree with him that we should look closely at it for 18 months and monitor it and, if it is working, perhaps sing its praises. But one thing we have to do is to test its credibility to the limit; make demands on it; and insist that it delivers if the ombudsman is to get a six-figure salary, which he or she will, and if the chairperson, the former Governor-General, is to get a six-figure salary. But the bill will be picked up by the banks, so the banks will be the employer of the ombudsman. It raises some pretty fundamental questions.

Senator Tate raised the question that certain decisions have been made by courts in Australia about Swiss bank loan disputes. I think he was almost arguing my case. He was citing the fact that the Swiss loans fiasco, which caught out approximately 1,400 Australians, was one aspect of the banking farce in this country which forced people to go into courts. Judgments are now being made in their favour which cite the fact that banks have abandoned their fundamental fiduciary relationship. For a while there I thought that the Minister for Justice was arguing my case for me because he was citing the very evidence that I have tabled in this Senate to the effect that, in many cases, the banks have abandoned those whose interests they are supposedly representing while they make their billions of dollars of profit every year.

If the Commonwealth Bank is to experience a 74 per cent increase in profit in the last 12 months and make super profits it obviously has to be at somebody's expense. If the four major banks in this country are announcing record profits, which they describe as super profits, and they are embarrassed by them, it obviously has to be at somebody's expense. It is at our expense. The best that the spokesperson for the Australian Bankers Association could do the other day to respond to these observations about their absurd, obscene levels of profit was to say, `If you think we are ripping you off now in the deregulated banking system you should know the realities about how we were ripping you off before deregulation'. That was the reaction of the Australian Bankers Association when, on the front page of the Sydney Morning Herald three or four days ago, the observation was made that the banks in this country operate at levels of profitability and margins twice those required by Swiss international banks and equivalent banks overseas.

Senator Stone's contribution to this debate this morning was nothing short of pathetic. It was really just a tirade against a group of senators whose political aspirations and ideas happened to differ from his; so he launched a tirade. We are used to it. He began the tirade by saying that I was taking up the time of the Senate in bringing before it the issue of banking in Australia today. I believe that my contribution has been much more constructive and much more legitimate, in terms of using the time of the Senate, than that outburst which we got. It really was classic bigotry of the old style that we listened to. As an adolescent I can remember being appalled by the bigotry between Masons and Catholics and that sort of blind rejection of the fact that other people might hold another point of view. We were subjected to classic bigotry in the chamber this morning but we have become accustomed to it.

Senator Stone said that it was all a pre-election gimmick by the Australian Democrats. I deliberately said at the beginning of my speech that it was a pre-election issue. That happens to be a coincidence, but it is a real pre-election issue and it is an issue that should be raised, heightened and made a primary election issue. That is exactly what we are trying to do. I do not believe that it is a gimmick or politicking; I believe that it is quite appropriate and legitimate for us to do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is irresponsible not to do it.
—Indeed, as Senator Coulter says, it would be utterly irresponsible of us not to do it. In fact, hundreds and thousands of Australians are pleading with us to do it, so that is what we are doing.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that Senator Stone also falsely argued some of the same propositions that Minister Tate argued-namely, our expectations of the Committee and the role of the courts in resolving these sorts of disputations. He then used some colourful phrases such as, `In the web of life we must expect some of these injustices from banks'. He then pleaded with us to expect these things in the web of life. I believe that one has to be discerning. I believe that it is our primary role to discern between reasonable and unreasonable expectations in the web of life and then try to rectify, on behalf of the community at large, some of the unreasonable expectations in the web of life. I mean, really, it was colourful phraseology, but it addressed only part of the realities of this web of life and it failed to acknowledge our role in relation to them. Of course, the language then became even more colourful when Senator Stone talked about the Democrats picking over the decaying carcass of social issues. The issues that we have picked over in the last 12 years have been issues like the environment, social justice, privacy and electoral reform. We have pursued those issues. Those have been some of the carcasses-to use the emotional phraseology of Senator Stone-that we, as a Senate, have been addressing in the last few days.

I urge every senator and every Australian to read the speeches of Senator Stone of today and of 5 April when he last addressed this motion. They will get great insight into where he stands on the issues of the day. He had the gall to stand there as the leader of a party with seven senators and direct abuse and ridicule at the leader of another party with seven senators. He grandstands his Party as a party that is on the move. Is he unaware of what will happen to his Party in Queensland in a few weeks from now? It really was the most extraordinarily superficial response. Did he actually address the serious issues which I had raised, of excessive interest rates, undisclosed charges and absurd profits? Not a word was addressed to any of these matters. But we got colourful phraseology about carcases, webs of life and pretentious power play from a leader of a party that has, really, the same standing numerically as the Australian Democrats in this chamber. Frankly, I do not believe that his Party pursues with as vigorous a social conscience as ours the issues that lie within the so-called carcases that he says that we pick over. I saw it just as an utterly pathetic response to a profoundly important issue.

I will continue to bring this issue back to the chamber. I do not believe it is wasting the time of the Senate to bring before it what we see as being the gross inadequacies, injustices and exploitations which are inherent in one of the most important social phenomena in society-banking. I make no apologies for bringing the matter before the Senate, and I will continue to do so. I will continue to try to blow up the storm I was referring to earlier.

I simply commend to the Senate and to the Australian people the proposition which we are now debating as a matter of Senate business-namely, that the most appropriate standing committee available to us should deliberate on a number of vitally important issues, but basically that the committee should look at the question whether the average Australian is being well served by the Australian banking system. It might well start by looking at the role of the Reserve Bank of Australia, as I read it in this chamber the other day; and it might well start that by looking at the duties of the Board of the Reserve Bank, which are to stabilise the currency, create full employment and ensure that the banking system of the land functions in the best interests of Australians.

The proposition before the chamber today is simply that that is not what is prevailing in Australia today and, therefore, the Board of the Reserve Bank is failing us. The Reserve Bank itself and the Government are failing us. Australians are being exploited by the most fundamental institutions in the land. They are all-powerful and are operating within a banking model created by this Government in 1984-85. It was specifically the brainchild of the present Treasurer (Mr Keating). It is sustained by the support of the Opposition and will be kept in place by the alternative government, the Opposition, should it be elected to power. But the victim, in every way, is the average Australian.

We have simply proposed that one of the standing committees investigate whether perhaps there is something rotten in the state of Denmark and come back and make recommendations to this chamber as to what can be done about it. I think that is an eminently responsible and sensible proposal for us to bring forward-populist or otherwise. In a pre-election context, it is a most timely occasion to bring the matter forward. It is apparent that the Government is seeing it in election terms. Its own backbenchers are screaming for such an inquiry. The Government has pulled it off. The Government backbenchers are screaming for such an inquiry because an election is coming up and because it is a populist demand. The Treasurer has said, `Let us kill it; because there is an election coming up and the inquiry will reveal the inadequacies of the policies the Government has put in place'. I commend the motion to the Senate as being extremely appropriate and very timely.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator McLean's) be agreed to.
