DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN FEDERAL POLICE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 4 October, on motion by Senator Tate:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will be supporting the Australian Federal Police Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989. The Bill introduces a form of fixed term contracts in the employment of the Australian Federal Police (AFP). The relationship between the Australian Federal Police and the Hawke Government over the last year or so has been somewhat unfortunate. One will recall that last year the AFP felt forced to take unprecedented industrial action because of the unsympathetic way in which the Australian Government was addressing its financial problems, particularly in the light of the tragic murder of Assistant Commissioner Winchester, and the inability of the Australian Government to properly appreciate that that investigation required considerable extra funding or, if the Government did appreciate that, its unwillingness to provide that funding. Unfortunately, relations between the Government and the AFP fell to an all-time low. Nevertheless, there are some positive aspects in this legislation and, if it indicates a growing confidence on the part of the AFP, it is something that we are pleased to note.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill applies to police officers and public servants who are employed by the AFP. Not surprisingly, we have followed the development of the Bill during the months that it has been debated in principle. In particular, we have been interested in the reaction of the Australian Federal Police Association (AFPA) and other relevant unions. We understand that the AFPA now supports the Bill although it has from time to time had reservations about part of it. The 13 other unions represented in the AFP-it is probably worth noting that there are still 13 other unions represented within the AFP, including the Public Service unions-oppose the Bill because they see it as one step towards contract employment. We believe the Bill has merit and we ask the unions to think again if they are of a mind to continue their opposition in ways that might be disruptive.

The Bill is part of the modernisation of the AFP. It follows on from the career structure review which took place earlier this year and which introduced broadbanding of ranks, merit promotion and other reforms. The Government now wishes to introduce two more major reforms, which it does by this Bill. The first is to put all AFP personnel, both police officers and public servants, under the Australian Federal Police Act. This is desirable to obtain flexibility in determining the overall complement of the AFP. The second reform is to abolish permanency of employment and replace it with fixed term contracts of employment. Police officers will be given the option to take a fixed term appointment or resign. Public servants now working in the AFP will have a choice of a fixed term appointment or being made subject to the mobility provisions of the Public Service Act.

The justification for fixed term appointments is that they give flexibility in managing the force. The needs of a police force change from time to time and management must have the flexibility to bring in officers with the skills that are needed and to be free of officers without those skills-those who have suffered burnout, as it is referred to, and those who have lost their enthusiasm and efficiency. Under the present system those who are incapable of being promoted, or who do not want to be promoted, must be kept on in employment because they have virtual permanency of employment. The system proposed in the Bill is that police officers and public servants in the AFP will all be on fixed term appointments which will be renewed only if the employees are efficient, productive and honest. If their appointments are not renewed at the end of their fixed term the employees will receive, by way of compensation, an adjustment of 12 1/2 per cent of their accumulated salary over the term of the contract. The Australian Federal Police Commissioner will have the power to fix the terms and conditions of employment subject to general policy guidelines given by the Minister for Justice. These guidelines will require adherence to the national wage case guidelines and the statutory authority coordination arrangements.

By this means most terms and conditions will continue to be determined by the Industrial Relations Commission through awards. It is proposed that a common award will be put before the Industrial Relations Commission. As a step in the right direction, the terms and conditions of the higher ranks of deputy commissioner or senior executive commissioned police officers, such as commanders, the assistant commissioners and senior executive public servants, are expressly removed from the jurisdiction of the Industrial Relations Commission. They will be determined by the Commissioner. A power is also proposed which will make temporary appointments for up to 12 months. This should add to the flexibility to be achieved by these changes. That is something that the Opposition is pleased to witness.

The Bill introduces reforms which are consistent with the coalition parties' industrial relations policy. We are pleased that the Government has seen the wisdom of that policy, as is demonstrated by this piece of legislation. I draw the attention of the Government to clause 1.15 of the Opposition's policy, dealing with the issue of public employment. It states:
We will adopt practices in the Commonwealth public sector that will set an example in the pursuit of flexible and harmonious workplace relations.
In clause 6.1 of the policy it is stated:
We will adopt a more flexible market oriented approach to industrial relations in the area of Commonwealth employment.
Paragraph 4 of the Opposition's public administration policy states:

In some cases it may be appropriate to move certain classes of employees outside award coverage altogether. This could be done through the use of voluntary agreements as set out in our industrial relations policy.

Therefore, it may be seen that, at least in part, this Bill is consistent with our policy. As I previously indicated, I commend the Government on moving in that direction. The fixed term appointments proposed by the Bill fall short of the full-blooded contracts that we would have in government. Constables, sergeants and superintendents will have hybrid fixed term appointments and their terms and conditions will be fixed mostly by awards. Only the term of the appointment and the adjustment payment will be fixed by a means other than the award-that is, by determination of the Commissioner. The scope of an individual police officer or public servant to negotiate his or her own terms is therefore limited. However, the contracts of the senior ranks of commanders, assistant commissioners, deputy commissioners and senior executive public servants will be capable of variation from officer to officer.

I reiterate that the Bill is a step forward, doing away with permanency of employment and requiring performance or termination of employment. In all the circumstances we believe that we should therefore recognise this Bill as a moderate advance towards contract employment. We will support it. I add, however, that we will watch very closely the administration of the Bill when it becomes law. In particular we will watch over those matters which have concerned the Australian Federal Police Association, which it has brought to the attention of my colleague the shadow Attorney-General, Mr Brown. For instance, we will watch over the workings of the internal review proceedings which will be used when decisions are made as to whether a contract will be reviewed. We will expect the Australian Federal Police and the Government to administer these new arrangements fairly, bearing in mind that they will be dealing with individuals, their careers and livelihoods. Otherwise I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to support the second reading of the Australian Federal Police Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989 I indicate that initially I was apprehensive about some aspects of this Bill. I want to make clear the nature of those reservations and the factors which overcame my concerns in this instance. Those apprehensions have been reinforced by some of the remarks made by Senator Hill in his support of the Bill. In my view it has always been an important feature of the Westminster system of government that public sector employees should have security of tenure. This has been premised upon the assumption that this security will enable such public servants to tender fair and frank advice, free from the threat of political persecution or other consequences that might follow, were their employment not so secure. I acknowledge that this description is a gross oversimplification of what is a very complex interrelationship between public servants, their Ministers and the government of the day. But it is that element of the principles underlying that relationship which led me to be apprehensive about this Bill. An inherent feature of this Bill is that there will be a change to that traditional relationship for one sector of Australian government employment.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not one who believes that tradition is, of itself, a case for retaining any particular feature, including the nature of Public Service employment. It may be that there is a case for review of the nature of public sector employment in the contemporary Australian version of the Westminster system. Senator Hill said that this is a step forward because it leads towards doing away with permanency. That is something that I think needs more careful consideration than the rather cavalier contribution that Senator Hill has just made and the even more grandiose and absurd suggestions made by the shadow Minister for public administration, Senator Bishop.

If we are to make major changes, as would be inherent in a move towards a contract system of tenure, I would wish to see such a change made in a considered and planned manner, after some sort of proper review or public debate of the pros and cons. I certainly would not welcome a major change initiated in an ad hoc manner in a relatively small part of the Public Service. I expressed those concerns within my Party, to the relevant Minister and to others. However, the second reading speech by the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) gives some assurances. The Minister in his second reading speech referred to the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris). He said:

There have been some concerns expressed as to the potentially wider implication of these proposals for other public sector employment. My colleague the Minister for Industrial Relations has confirmed that during the discussions that led to this Bill those particular concerns were canvassed. He has stated that fixed term appointment in the Australian Federal Police is a response to a set of unique circumstances and should not be seen in any way as providing a basis for moves to fixed term contract employment in other areas.

I welcome that commitment by the Minister for Industrial Relations, as the responsible Minister for that matter. I do, of course, recognise that there are special circumstances in the Australian Federal Police (AFP). As the Minister for Justice said in his second reading speech, the Bill will enable, wherever possible, positions which do not require police powers to be filled by civilian staff, which will result in a better utilisation of scarce police resources. I acknowledge that there is growing significance in the development of an overlap of activities by police and civilian employees of the AFP.

Furthermore, as the Minister said, the Bill will allow for-and it is his description, but I share it-the development of a professional and dedicated work force which is purpose designed for the unique task of Federal law enforcement. It is not only a unique area of Federal government employment, but also it is a quite different sort of police force in many ways from those in the States. Therefore, there is certainly a case for saying that the very nature of policing lends itself to a fixed term tenure system and that probably explains why the Australian Federal Police Association has supported this proposal-not unanimously, not without reservation, but in the end it supported it.

A particularly important element, which I am pleased that Senator Hill also referred to, is the stress that policing places upon individual officers, which tends to lead-to use that overused phrase-to burnout among members of that force. Evidence which has been raised in discussions indicates that the overall term of employment of officers of the Australian Federal Police at the moment is in the area of 10 years-approximately 11 years. For this reason, and to take proper account of this significant stress element and the consequential staff turnover, the fixed term appointment system may well prove to be well suited to the requirements of the AFP. We have always had special and unique employment arrangements for members of the defence forces, although they are Australian Government employees. Doing that in the AFP is not of itself a precedent but it is important that it does not become a step on the road to doing away with permanency unless we undertake a very broad-ranging and considered review and decide that in some way that should be done.

There is another element that nobody has sought to emphasise greatly, although I do not wish to dramatise the matter. It is quite significant or, as the Minister said, `noteworthy', that this type of appointment to police forces was a recommendation of the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct in Queensland. Mr Fitzgerald's report and recommendations would appear to me to indicate that this initiative should facilitate the maintenance of the high levels of integrity that we have within the Australian Federal Police. I do not want to dwell on that but I think it is important.

As I have said, the proposals in this Bill relate only to the AFP. They recognise the unique environment in which the AFP operates. It is important to note that this is not a change which is cost driven; it is not about reducing conditions of service of employees; it is not about reducing the rights of unions to represent their members; and it does not conform to the industrial relations agenda espoused by some on the conservative side of Australian politics. All conditions of service and union rights will be retained. There are some details of the proposed changes about which concern has been expressed, particularly by the Public Sector Union, and the effect of these will need to be monitored. I will certainly be doing so. It is significant to note, to ensure that there is no misunderstanding, that the terms of these contracts for staff of the AFP will be determined by the Industrial Relations Commission through the normal award making procedures. I think that is important and worth while and I support it.

These changes are about ensuring that the AFP is able to obtain and retain honest, competent and hardworking employees and are designed to act as a disincentive to corruption. I am sure everybody in this Senate and everybody in Australia-with isolated exceptions-would want to ensure that the AFP is able to maintain its high standard of effectiveness, accountability and integrity. Therefore, I support the Bill and will be following very closely the development of the new employment system. I would be even more enthusiastic if I thought that this Bill might serve as a catalyst to a continuing debate on the nature of Public Service employment. That would be a very worthwhile debate which would enhance Australian political dialogue and discussion in our democracy. I would welcome that continuing debate but I suspect that it might be a bit too much to ask. Without getting my hopes up too high in that area, I support the Bill.

I am hopeful that the cooperation between the two arms of crime control that are under Federal jurisdiction will be fruitful. TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I rise to close the debate on this extremely important legislation, the Australian Federal Police Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989. It is extremely important that the Australian Federal Police (AFP), its police and staff members, know that this whole chamber of the Parliament is behind the Australian Federal Police Commissioner in the very necessary restructuring and refocusing of the AFP so that it might better discharge the very onerous duties which we as an Australia-wide community place on its shoulders.

SPEECH.PARA: Much can be done by way of award restructuring, administrative arrangements and so on, but there comes a time when it is important-and it has proved necessary-that the Federal Parliament indicate in a Bill such as this that the very necessary and considerable restructuring required in the AFP is being undertaken with wholehearted non-partisan support of all members of the Parliament. I am extremely anxious that the Australian Federal Police understand that that is the case. As I say, I pay tribute particularly to honourable senators who have indicated that today.

I believe that the tenth anniversary of the Australian Federal Police, which by coincidence we are celebrating at about this time, is a most auspicious time for this legislation to be passed through the Federal Parliament. It really puts the seal on the achievements of the last decade under Sir Colin Woods, Major-General Grey, and now Mr Peter McAulay, and sets the stage for another decade of great achievement as we move into the next century-indeed the next millennium-the second century of this great Commonwealth of Australia, this Federation.

It is in regard to the nationwide Federal Commonwealth responsibilities of the Australian Federal Police that much of the restructuring is designed to help achieve a capacity to ensure that we as a nation live in a law-abiding and, so far as is possible federally, a crime-free society. But, in focusing on that, we must not forget the very important role that the Australian Federal Police plays here in the Australian Capital Territory. Indeed, within this Territory its community policing role is an extremely important one and one which the Chief Minister of the Australian Capital Territory and I have had many discussions about over the last several weeks. This has led to the setting up of a working party which will ensure that the Australian Federal Police continues to give great service to this community here in Canberra.

In this tenth anniversary year it is extremely heartening for me as a Minister to know that the members of the Australian Federal Police-both the police members and the staff members-themselves are supportive of what is a most radical and innovative change in the way in which policing is to be organised in Australia. To move with the consent of so many members of the Australian Federal Police to a less quasi-military and less bureaucratic model is a very considerable achievement which could not occur-and will not succeed, whatever the Federal Parliament says-without the concurrence and willingness to give the proposals a go which I believe has been indicated by the Australian Federal Police membership. I am very grateful to the ordinary members and their various elected representatives, who have brought about this quality of appreciation of what is at stake. This has enabled the Commissioner's proposals-supported as they are by the Government and the Federal parliamentary Labor Party-to be brought into this chamber and to gather the support which they have from all sides.

In speaking of the parliamentary Labor Party, I should like to pay a special tribute to several members of the Caucus, to Senator McMullan, who has spoken, to Senator Barney Cooney and to Mr Langmore, a member of the House of Representatives. They have called on me on three or four occasions to express their concerns, their misgivings and how these might be remedied. I think they have been extremely fruitful discussions. Senator Zakharov and Senator Giles have also, in the relevant parliamentary Caucus committee, indicated their concerns and played their part in ensuring that award conditions of members of the Australian Federal Police are properly attended to and protected.

As a result of approaches made to me in late September by the triumvirate of Senator McMullan and Senator Cooney and Mr Langmore, I had discussions with the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Peter Morris, which led to his writing me a letter in the following terms:
My Dear Minister,
Yesterday we discussed the Government's proposals for fixed term appointments to a unified work force for the Australian Federal Police.
You indicated to me concerns expressed by some of our Caucus colleagues as to the potentially wider implication of these proposals for other public sector employment.

I wish to confirm that during the discussions that led to this proposal those particular concerns were canvassed. Fixed term appointment in the Australian Federal Police is a response to a set of unique circumstances and should not be seen in any way as providing a basis for moves to fixed term contract employment in other areas.
Yours sincerely,
PETER MORRIS

Indeed, it was as a direct result of those representations by Senator McMullan, Senator Cooney and Mr John Langmore that I secured that written understanding of what I had conveyed to them as being the intention and the tenor of the discussions in Cabinet in relation to these matters, which led to the second reading being amended to make that clear in the way in which Senator McMullan indicated in his contribution. I thank them for providing an opportunity to place that on the record in this way, due to their very persistent and, I must say, extremely effective lobbying on this matter.

The fixed term appointments to a unified work force of the Australian Federal Police are not a precursor to wider reorganisation along these lines in the Australian Public Service. If it is a precursor, as Senator Macklin pointed out today, perhaps it will be a precursor to very necessary changes in other police forces around Australia. Indeed, Mr Tony Fitzgerald, in his very famous report after his inquiry in Queensland, indicated that he thought that the fixed term contract was the best way in which a police force might be organised. I hope that the incoming Labor administration in Queensland, after the next election, will take up his proposal.

Senator Macklin raised a matter which was apparently raised in the Scrutiny of Bills Committee and which was the subject of an Alert Digest from that Committee, received, I think, yesterday. I have not had time to fully consider it, but I will speak about the tabling of ministerial guidelines. During the parliamentary debate on the Australian Federal Police Act 1979, the then responsible Minister undertook to table any ministerial guidelines made under the Act, and this practice has been followed. I assure the Committee that any written ministerial policy guidelines given to the Commissioner of Police under the new Australian Federal Police Act will be tabled for the information of Parliament. Given the exigencies of the timetable for legislation this session, I will not give an explicit undertaking, but I do not see why that practice could not be contained in the legislation. I can assure Senator Macklin and the Scrutiny of Bills Committee of my good faith in that matter, and I will certainly ensure that that is made a provision of the omnibus Bill next year. I have not had a chance to look at the other matter raised by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee in its Alert Digest, but I understand it could be the subject of a reply to that Committee in the next week or so and need not hold up the passage of this legislation. I repeat that, in the tenth anniversary year of the formation of the Australian Federal Police, this Federal Parliament is here given an opportunity to ensure that the Federal Police force is structured in a way which will enable it to achieve its objectives and goals, which are objectives and goals set on behalf of us all as residents-the fortunate inhabitants-of this great Commonwealth of Australia. I believe that the AFP, under its present Commissioner, Mr Peter McAulay, is moving in a way which will certainly satisfy this Parliament as it seeks to achieve those objectives and goals. I thank the Parliament for its support for this legislation.

As the Senate will be aware, it is now two months since the 1989-90 Budget, which is the subject of the Appropriation Bills we are debating today, was delivered by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in the other place. It is obvious from the major economic statistics released during the last few days that the Government's economic policies are already, in the short space of two months, way off course. This Budget has provided no answer to Australia's fundamental economic problems. Both international credit rating agencies, Moody's Investors Service and Standard and Poor's Corporation, have now twice downgraded Australia's credit rating in the international bond markets.

The Reserve Bank of Australia, in its annual report delivered shortly after the Budget, has extensively criticised the Government's inadequate, one-dimensional tight monetary policy and the high interest rate regime, pointing out that while, of course, interest rates of the magnitude which the Treasurer has now put in place can be expected in time to dampen down demand, to cool the overheated economy-to use the Treasurer's words-if too long prolonged-they have now been in place for almost 18 months-such interest rates can also have a counterproductive effect because they tend to kill off the business investment, the provision of which is in the end part of the only solution to our economic problems-namely, to lift our national productivity.

Yesterday's consumer price index released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics showed inflation running at around 8.3 per cent for the 12 months ended the September quarter. I interpolate the comment that the Government has done a good job in selling to our commentators the view that the annual inflation rate for the 12 months ended September is 8 per cent. If our journalists were to read the release put out by the Australian Statistician, they would see that the Statistician points out that for analytical purposes-that is, economic analytical purposes as distinct from the purposes of legal contracts and other such uses-the appropriate figure for the 12 months ended September quarter is not 8 per cent, but 8.3 per cent. I hope that that is clearly established and that the Government does not seek to deny it.

What happened to the Treasurer's forecast of just 14 months ago in the 1988 Budget that by 1989-90-that is, the financial year we are now in-inflation would be running at between 3 per cent and 4 per cent? We now have an inflation rate running at between 8 per cent and 9 per cent, and seemingly stuck in that range. Only earlier this week I gave the Government the benefit of the doubt by saying that it seemed as though inflation was stuck at between 7 per cent and 8 per cent. I have had to revise my view. It is obviously stuck at between 8 per cent and 9 per cent. The Treasurer's forecast of 14 months ago was blown out of the water because, among other things, it was based on a grab for votes, with an election timing policy plan in mind, obviously, through an irrational and unsustainable wage-tax trade-off with the Australian Council of Trade Unions that simply could never be delivered except at the cost of blowing out these major aggregates, including not least the aggregate of foreign debt, on which we have also had some further confirmatory figures published this week.

We all make forecasts and are confounded by the results but in this area at any rate I can claim to have very accurately forecast this outcome in a paper delivered on 2 September last year to the Business Congress of the Australian Economists Conference held in the Canberra Hyatt Hotel, in which just after the Budget was delivered I made it very plain that the Treasurer's wage-tax trade-off deal was simply non-deliverable and that if it were to be delivered, it would be disastrous. Of course, we are now experiencing the disaster that the Treasurer has delivered, not just to his Party but also to the people of this country.

This Government's accord with the trade union movement has done nothing more than perpetuate inflation at these high levels. That inflation, and particularly the wage inflation that goes with it, perpetuates bracket creep and high taxation levels. It perpetuates that ever-growing gush of money into the Government's coffers, something which the Opposition is simply not prepared to countenance any longer. We have given a commitment to return the proceeds of what the economists call the bracket creep process, and we shall do so in our first Budget. Assuming that there is an election before the middle of next year, we shall have a Budget presumably by around August of next year. In that Budget we shall deliver on that commitment by way of our first instalment. Will the Government give a similar commitment? If the Treasurer will not give a commitment to return bracket creep to the taxpayers, it simply means that he and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) support even higher taxation under their high inflation rate regime.

I have mentioned yesterday's figures on the consumer price index. On Wednesday of this week we had another in the now long string of terrible-in the sense of frightening-balance of payments deficit figures. Seasonally adjusted, the current account deficit for the month of September alone was just over $2,000m-$2,016m. We failed to pay our way in the world by $2,016m in one month on a seasonally adjusted basis. For the three months ended September that means we have failed to pay our way in the world, on a seasonally adjusted basis, by $5.8 billion-over $5,800m.

This means that the balance of payments figures forecast in this year's Budget also are already, despite protests to the contrary from both the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, and the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) when he returned yesterday, beginning to blow out, just as they were doing at this time last year in respect of the forecast in the 1988-89 Budget. The Government will have to answer this. Either what I have said is true-that the balance of payments forecast in the Budget is blowing out-or, if it is not, the Government will have to tell us how we are going to get the balance of payments deficits in the second half of this financial year-that is, the first half of 1990-down to not much more than $1 billion a month. I remind you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that for the last three months they have been running at just under $2 billion a month.

How will that precipitous decline in the balance of payments deficit come about within the next three months? How will it happen? It will not. I imagine that in the next three months we cannot look forward to a dramatic jump in our exports. On the whole our exports have been doing quite well and I expect to see them continue doing quite well. But we are not looking forward to a 25 per cent increase in our export performance three months from now. We are certainly not looking forward to any improvement at all in what is called the net income deficit-the amount which we are required to pay out month by month to our foreign creditors on that $108 billion of net foreign debt which we had at 30 June this year. That interest bill will not diminish, nor will the other form of property income payments on foreign ownership of this country diminish in the next three months.

There is only one way in which the balance of payments deficit can fall from its present level of just under $2 billion per month to not much more than $1 billion per month only three months from now-and that is by a howling recession. The Government will have to answer this. Either we are right when we say that the balance of payments forecast in the Budget is already shown to be totally and hopelessly wrong again, or, if we are wrong in that regard and if the balance of payments forecast will be right after all, is it not the case that the only way in which it can be right is through a major recession developing in the first half of next calendar year? The Government will have to answer that question. It need not think that it can go on evading it. We will keep putting the question to it. Sooner or later Mr Keating will have his back against the wall and some journalist will have the courage to ask him that question and to keep on asking him until he answers it.

I think the result will probably be somewhere between the two. I suspect that in 1989-90 we will see the balance of payments deficit blow out beyond the Government's Budget forecast but probably not as much as we might think by looking just at the figures for the last three months. Some recession in the economy will begin in the first half of next year-as to the precise time, I hazard no guess-that will begin to bring imports down somewhat and therefore make the balance of payments look temporarily a bit better. But the Government has not admitted to either of those outcomes as yet. It will. I promise it, it will.

I ask: What have we had from Mr Keating in response to the $2 billion deficit on the balance of payments announced last Wednesday? We have had him simply expressing relief and suggesting that at last the Government's policies are working-when we have such a balance of payments figure in seasonally adjusted terms! If the Government does not like the seasonally adjusted estimate that the Australian Statistician now produces-the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) at Question Time yesterday did not even know those figures existed-let it look at the raw figures, the original data, at the $1,777m deficit, I think it was, recorded in September. How can we have arrived at a situation in which a Treasurer of the Commonwealth of Australia goes out and tells the market to breath a sigh of relief because we have had a balance of payments deficit in the month of `only' just over $1.77 billion?

As the Opposition's Economic Action Plan, released by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) on 12 October last states, there have been only two occasions in our country's entire history-only one occasion since Federation-when the external debt burden has accelerated as rapidly as we are now seeing: the first was in the last century in the 1880s before Federation and the second was in the late 1920s. On those occasions the service ratio of gross property income rose very rapidly, topping out at about 40 per cent of gross national product in 1890 and in 1931. Last financial year we had exports growing at one per cent and imports growing at 25 per cent. Australia now ranks third in the size of our debt to commercial foreign banks behind only Brazil and Mexico. That is the distinction which we have achieved under this Government. The Empire State Building which Mr Keating has built-as he called it earlier this week in the House of Representatives-consists of $108 billion of net foreign debt, second only in commercial banking debt terms to Mexico and Brazil.

TALK.START.PARA: —More like King Kong climbing up the side of it at the moment.

—I agree with my colleague. What is Mr Keating's answer to these points? It is effectively, `Don't worry, be happy! All that growth in imports is in the form of capital goods and will in due course at some time improve our export performance'. Where is the evidence? The people of this country have long ceased taking Mr Keating's word for things. They have begun to notice in recent days that that word changes a lot from time to time depending on the debate of the day.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators will remember the massive boost in export production we were to get after 1986, in the aftermath of the famous banana republic statement and the then policies of the Government-which at least were more directed to our problems than the policies of the last two years or so have been-which were to produce a massive increase in exports too. Do honourable senators remember the J-curve? Has anybody heard about the J-curve in the last year or two? Perhaps if this Government is here long enough and should we see our exchange rate decline massively as it did during 1985 and 1986 we will hear the Treasurer once again pump up the J-curve rhetoric.

In the office of Treasurer today we have a man who has failed. He has failed himself. He has failed his Party and, most importantly, he has failed Australia. The fact is that only about $2 billion-to take a generous estimate-of the $5 1/2 billion deterioration in the balance of payments last financial year can be identified to an increase in capital goods imports. There has been some such increase and I welcome that. But to say that that is the reason for the deterioration in the balance of payments situation is, to use a kindly phrase, to handle the truth carelessly. Since the last election we have had two wasted years. We have had a government which told us that this will be the term of office of the Hawke-Keating Government in which it will embark upon a massive program of micro-economic reform for fixing up the heartland of Australia. We were to have a privatisation program of all of those less than wholly efficient government business enterprises. We were to have a reform of the waterfront. We were to have something done about the coastal shipping shambles whereby it costs more to send goods from Melbourne to Hobart than it does from Hobart to Tokyo.

TALK.START.PARA: —All we have had have been inquiries.

—Yes, and consultation with the trade unions. The fact is that we have nothing happening on any of those fronts except a decision by the Government to provide $155m of taxpayers' money to pay off and retire 3,000 waterside workers with golden handshakes of $100,000 apiece on average-including the money provided by waterside employers-having spent their lives drawing very large wages and salaries for doing mighty little.

SPEECH.PARA: Where are the Government's policies to deal with our problems today? There are no policies. The Opposition by contrast has, culminating in its Economic Action Plan of a fortnight ago, a whole series of publications of policy-32 in all. The Government today has none. However, as the second reading amendment that I have circulated notes, there is an urgent need for the Government to adopt our policies or something very like them. The credit rating agencies had something to say about the one claim that this Government makes for responsible fiscal policies, namely, the massive size of the Budget surplus. Moody's in August this year stated:

Moody's noted that the recent federal budget covering the current 1989-90 fiscal year generates an even larger surplus and contributes to the needed growth in national savings. Nevertheless, the rating agency believes that the budget fails to decisively address the issues of external imbalance and productivity.

That is exactly what we have said in our Economic Action Plan. The areas of external imbalance and productivity are those that the Opposition's Economic Action Plan seeks to address. Because I see we are approaching the time for questions I will conclude these remarks by foreshadowing the second reading amendment standing in my name.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I refer to the attack made by Senator Tambling during Tuesday evening's adjournment debate on Mr Pat Dodson in the latter's capacity as a commissioner with the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. I refer in particular to Senator Tambling's implication that Mr Dodson is unqualified for the position and that he was appointed because he is, to use Senator Tambling's words, one of the `mates of the Minister'. Will the Minister comment on this claim and on Mr Dodson's suitability or otherwise for the position he holds?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did read with some dismay the Hansard of the adjournment debate of 24 October in which Senator Tambling seriously questioned the qualification of Commissioner Dodson to undertake the work that has been given to him as one of the commissioners of the inquiry into Aboriginal deaths in custody. I also was very upset-I cannot say I was amazed-by his statement:

ANSWER.PARA: It is also very important to question why mates of the Minister are given these responsibilities.
In my view, this amounts to a scurrilous attack on Mr Pat Dodson. The implication is that Mr Hand had indulged in some sort of cronyism in arranging the appointment of Mr Dodson as a commissioner.

I think it is important to put on the record that Mr Pat Dodson is a very capable and well experienced person. He is a member of the Yaoro Aboriginal tribe and was born in Broome in January 1948. He was educated in the Northern Territory and Victoria and became a Catholic priest in the early 1970s. After leaving active pastoral duties, he became manager of information and education at the Central Land Council in 1983 and its director in 1986. He was appointed to the additional position of Acting Deputy Chairman of the Aboriginal Development Commission in May last year. There is no doubt that his capability and experience would be extremely helpful to the royal commission.

The real point I want to make is that the suggestion that Mr Pat Dodson be appointed to the royal commission did not come from Mr Hand or, indeed, from me. The suggestion was made to us, I think about Easter of this year, by Elliott Johnston, QC, the successor to Mr Muirhead as the chief commissioner, if you like, of the Aboriginal deaths in custody inquiry. Mr Johnston was concerned, as was Commissioner O'Dea, about the huge workload in Western Australia, where there are 33 reported deaths. It was decided that, rather than appointing two commissioners with identical terms of reference, responsibility would be divided functionally so that Mr O'Dea, the existing commissioner, would concentrate on hearing individual cases and the new commissioner would inquire into underlying factors-social, cultural, legal and so on-associated with the deaths.

The fact is that not only did Mr Elliott Johnston make the suggestion but it was taken up with great enthusiasm by Mr Peter Dowding, the Premier of Western Australia, whose position in regard to the commission at that stage was quite hostile. But Mr Dowding indicated, in conversations that I had with him, support for the appointment of Mr Dodson, which, as I say, was necessary if the commission's work was to progress satisfactorily in Western Australia. The suggestion that Mr Dodson's services be sought for this joint royal commission was made by Elliott Johnston, QC, and the matter was taken up with enthusiasm by the Premier of Western Australia. It was on that basis that the appointment was made. It certainly was not made by Mr Gerry Hand. He certainly was not appointed because he was a mate of the Minister, whatever that sort of coloured phrase is meant to imply.

Mr Dodson was appointed part time from 1 July 1989 and full time from 1 August 1989. It is important to note, in view of some of the publicity that has been generated by Senator Tambling, that the cost of Commissioner Dodson's office will be substantially less than the cost of each of the other commissioners' offices, which average, approximately, $1,970,000. Savings will be achieved because there will not be the same sort of need for formal legal oriented hearings and the court reporting and witness expenses associated with them. There will be fewer staff and, being located in Broome, there will not be the costs associated with capital city offices.

I believe that Senator Tambling has been way off the mark in his criticism of the appointment of Mr Pat Dodson. Indeed, I reject utterly the sort of scurrilous attack and the continuous denigration of not only a good Australian such as Pat Dodson, who is undertaking this task on behalf of two governments, but also the implication that he obtained the appointment because of a network of cronyism under the patronage of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Gerry Hand.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to recent reports indicating that the Federal Government has protested to the Chinese Government over the lack of protection for Australian diplomats in China facing increasingly violent demonstrations. Has the Chinese Government given any assurance that security will be stepped up in this area and how serious is the threat to the safety of Australian personnel? What steps has the Government taken to deal with the problem in Australia which has given rise to the demonstrations in China?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very concerned about reports of increasingly unruly and angry demonstrations outside our Shanghai Consulate-General on the language studies issue. High level recommendations were made to the Chinese authorities on Wednesday this week. My Department called in the Chinese Ambassador, Zhang Zai; our Ambassador in Beijing also called on the Foreign Ministry; and the Consul-General has been in constant contact with the Shanghai authorities. The purpose of these various representations was to request provision of adequate protection for consular staff and property and guarantees that the Consulate-General would be able to function normally. We were given firm assurances that the Shanghai authorities would be asked to take all necessary measures. However, yesterday, 26 October, a large crowd again gathered outside. The mood was angry; police protection was manifestly inadequate; and staff were prevented from leaving the premises. Following urgent representations in both Shanghai and Beijing, adequate police protection was then provided, enabling staff to leave.

ANSWER.PARA: As a result of these continuing disturbances, the Consul-General, in consultation with the Ambassador in Beijing, decided to close the Consulate temporarily to give the situation a chance to settle down. I support that decision and I make it clear again that it is the responsibility of the Chinese authorities to provide the protection necessary to enable the Consulate-General to discharge its normal functions. Of course, it is also the Government's responsibility, which I acknowledge, to try to remove, or at least address, the underlying causes that are producing the demonstrations. They flow from the Government decision of 30 August to change the English language intensive courses for overseas students entry criteria which affected the huge backlog of applicants for ELICOS courses. Resultant changes in criteria caused uncertainty in the minds of many applicants regarding their eligibility and, if ineligible, about the refund of their pre-paid fees.

To address these concerns, the Government has done a number of things. It has strengthened staffing in Beijing to accelerate processing of applications to remove the uncertainty of the threshold. It has negotiated an agreement, announced at the beginning of this week, with the Association of Recognised ELICOS Centres to refund fully all pre-paid fees and to make, in addition to that, a $100 goodwill payment, which is not to be a precedent for the future, but is a reflection of the financial cost that has been borne by those students who in good faith invested or borrowed large sums of money to put themselves in a position to take advantage of these courses which they are now not able to follow up. We have also agreed to examine the case for temporary financial assistance where it is independently determined that ELICOS institutions face substantial difficulties as a result of these arrangements. It is our intention, provided there is proper independent determination of this and not just a try-on, to ensure that the money that is owing to these students is paid. The ELICOS Association has also agreed that under these arrangements speedy refunds would be made. Constant discussions are taking place to ensure that that occurs.

The Government fully appreciates the disappointment that is motivating these students. I am certainly not suggesting that they do not have the right to demonstrate peacefully and express those concerns: far from it. Realistically, there is not much that we can do to alleviate the disappointment of those who will now miss out on access to Australia as a result of the new rules which, I think, are widely understood in the Australian community. But those who are worried about losing their money have had their concerns addressed. I hope that that message will get through more rapidly than it seems to have got through to date and that, as a result, we will see a progressive alleviation of the very disconcerting situation that presently exists in Shanghai.

ANSWER.PARA: Relationships between councils and Aboriginal communities can be improved . . . in a number of ways:

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Defence whether it is true that a United States naval battle group with 9,000 men, centred on the USS Midway, is currently in Mombasa and scheduled to go from there to Diego Garcia and then to arrive in Fremantle between 10 and 15 November. Is it also true that another battle group centred on the USS Enterprise and currently on a world tour, either heading for or in the Philippines, is due to arrive in Australia in December? I ask whether the Minister is aware of the fact that the USS Enterprise is powered by eight nuclear reactors and carries around 125 nuclear weapons on board, information which is available in the Parliamentary Library? I ask my final question in light of the recent report of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on contingency planning for the accidental release of ionising radiation and the latest Defencetrac public opinion poll, which shows that only 30 per cent of Australians support visits by nuclear powered warships and only 26 per cent support visits by nuclear armed warships. Which ports will this battle group visit? Will it include any of the ports, such as Hobart, which the report recommended should not host such visits?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —It is generally the Government's practice not to disclose details of visits by foreign warships until shortly before a visit takes place, when a public announcement is made. The Minister for Defence is aware of the propulsion system of the USS Enterprise, but he will not comment on whether it is carrying nuclear weapons. The Government has made it clear that it is considering the recommendations of the Senate Committee and it will respond to them in Parliament shortly. Were they worse off or better off than they were six months before? I want a simple answer-yes or no. Were the 119,500 pensioners worse off or better off after that adjustment?
—They would certainly be worse off under a coalition government.

—Is the Minister for Resources aware of a report by ACIL Australia Pty Ltd entitled The Impact of Tax on Gold Mining Income: Implications for the Future of the Industry and the Western Australian Economy? Does this report claim that the extension of company tax to the goldmining industry from 1 January 1991 will result in job losses and production losses? What is the Federal Government's attitude towards this report?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the report. It was Mark Twain who said there are `lies, damned lies, and statistics'. On that ascending scale of condemnation this report would have to rate as one of Mark Twain's statistics. The document was commissioned by the Association of Mining and Exploration Companies Inc. as a basis for trying to provide some `scientific' justification for what was a pretty shoddy effort by way of a campaign being run against this Government and now, as a consequence of the Liberal Party's new vision on this subject, against the coalition as well, on our commitment to extend company tax to goldmining operations in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: The key finding of the report is that the payment by goldmining companies or gold exploration companies of ordinary corporate taxation would mean a reduction in gold production in Western Australia by about 20 per cent, resulting in a net loss of 6,000 jobs, a loss to the State income of $300m, and a lump sum capital loss of $3.7 billion. Those conclusions, like many conclusions of lobby groups, are fashioned to justify an argument rather than objectively working out what is the case and what the objective truths are. I think this type of survey would be laughed out of court in academic circles. The Association's first problem is methodological. It asked gold companies to forecast their activities and how they would be modified in the future because of the introduction of ordinary corporate tax. The forecasts were to relate to the period between May and November last year. The sample size was 32 exploration and mining companies. Over 420 companies are exploring for gold and mining gold in Western Australia, approximately 100 of whom are miners and 320 explorers. It appears that none of the larger companies-companies that would actually have forward forecasting-were included in the sample; therefore, if smaller companies that were not as well organised as the major companies were asked, it is unlikely that they would have had plans. So in that case the survey would be biased.

There is no satisfactory exposition in the survey of the methodology used, so there is no process by which one can check the results. For example, we do not know how many forms were sent out soliciting information and what the response rate was on the returned forms. We do not know how many refused to comply with the survey on the grounds of commercial in-confidence and we do not know how many companies actually have forwarded plans for 1991-92. I would suggest that there was inadequate consideration of other phenomena which might impact on the mining industry: for example, what world bullion prices are and how they move; what type of incentive that provides for further exploration effort; and the fact that the industry in Australia has boomed and is peaking. A graph which simply projects that the boom will be endless would be a silly representation of where the industry is at.

However, I am advised that, using information gleaned from this report, an alternative conclusion is that there would not be a $3.7 billion capital loss but a $2.5 billion capital gain. So without an exposition of the methodology it is hard to work out exactly why that conclusion is as it is. I am also advised by the Western Australian Department of Mines that 8,844 people are employed in the goldmining industry in Western Australia. ACIL seemed to assume that for every one percentage point reduction in production there would be a loss of 120 jobs. That means that, in total, 2,400 jobs would be lost. It then multiplied that figure by 2.5 and came to a conclusion of 6,000. It has not justified why the multiplier is 2.5. I can only say that it is a figure that was plucked out of the air. As a consequence of those sorts of errors, the Mark Twain ascending list of condemnation indeed applies appropriately to this case.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories disappointed that Cabinet saw fit to approve pay-outs of $100,000 to 3,000 voluntarily redundant waterside workers while allowing maximum retirement payments of only $30,000 to timber workers made redundant by World Heritage listing in north Queensland? Does this substantial difference in payments to two groups who are to lose their jobs due to government decisions mean that a waterside worker is worth three times more than a timber worker, or does it mean that the Minister for Transport and Communications is three times more effective in Cabinet than the Minister for the Environment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not dare judge who was more or less effective in Cabinet. Had I been there I might have been supportive of the Minister for Transport and Communications, but I was not at the Cabinet meeting that made the decision.
—You weren't at the Caucus meeting on the day?

—I think at the time I was putting up with an Estimates committee that went on all day, which means that, occasionally, a few Ministers cannot get to Caucus meetings. Payments to workers who are retiring, being retrenched or whatever in these circumstances always have to have some relationship to the income. The income of workers is usually determined by what the market will pay. The market has been paying the waterside workers a lot of money for a long time. Whether that is justified is entirely a matter of opinion; obviously the market and the Government do not believe that that can go on forever and that is why so many of them are being retrenched.

ANSWER.PARA: Unfortunately, as Senator Boswell would be well aware but has never admitted in this chamber, timber workers in north Queensland were paid pathetic amounts of money by their employers; unionism was always discouraged; there were no redundancy packages for them whatsoever. They were the worst treated workers I have ever come across. Since the Government made its courageous and correct decision in north Queensland those workers have moved on to other jobs and are now doing very much better, as is north Queensland. That is why the issue has died so much in north Queensland. That is why we have won Federal seats on the issue and will now win State seats on it as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade Negotiations. As the Minister is no doubt aware, earlier this week the United States of America presented a plan aimed at removing agricultural trade barriers and reforming world farm produce trade. Will the Minister inform the Senate what this proposal will mean for Australian primary producers and what effect it will have on United States subsidy levels? Is the Australian Government likely to support the plan?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate will be well aware that Australia, as an efficient producer of a wide range of agricultural commodities, has much to gain if the negotiations on agriculture, currently under way as part of the Uruguay Round of Multilateral Trade Negotiations, are successful in addressing the problems which currently bedevil world trade and agriculture-problems such as high levels of domestic support, protection and export subsidies. Australia, as a member of the Cairns Group under the very effective chairmanship of Michael Duffy, has been instrumental in advancing the progress of the negotiations. The United States proposal to which Senator Foreman refers draws heavily on ideas that have been promulgated by the Cairns Group. We are, therefore, very pleased with the proposal as it is clearly in line with the long term objectives of the agricultural negotiations to establish a fair and market-oriented agricultural trading system. At the heart of the United States proposal is the proposed conversion of import access barriers to tariffs and the eventual prohibition of export subsidies, and the most prevalent are trade distorting, internal support measures. The highly trade distorting nature of export subsidies is recognised and an accelerated five-year phase-down is proposed.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator asked me what effect all this would have on Australian primary producers. The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics, in a study on United States grain policies in the world market, which was released just yesterday, estimated that the cost to Australia of the price discriminatory element alone of the United States export enhancement program in 1987 and 1988 was in the order of $US150m to $US238m. The United States has been reported as claiming that, were its proposal to be accepted by participants in the agricultural negotiations in Geneva, the benefit to consumers and taxpayers worldwide would be more than $US275 billion a year. The benefit to Australia's efficient primary producers, over the long term, again would amount to billions of dollars. Mr Duffy has already expressed Australia's support for the general thrust of the United States proposal in his recent discussions with the United States Trade Representative Carla Hills. The Cairns Group is currently developing its own comprehensive negotiating proposal prior to the next ministerial meeting of the group, which Mr Duffy will chair in Chiang Mai in Thailand on 21 to 23 November.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Does he recall my question to him on 1 September 1989 about the young soldier whose uniform had not been replaced despite his having grown out of it eight months earlier? Does the Minister also recall his promise to do something about it immediately and his further promise in his supplementary answer on 5 September that the soldier `is entitled to a replacement uniform and will be so issued'? Is the Minister aware that, despite the passage of eight weeks, the young soldier has not been so issued or even been contacted about the provision of a new uniform? What will the Minister do about yet another broken promise on the part of this Government? Will the Minister ensure that a new uniform is provided immediately, or will the soldier have to wait another eight weeks and look hopefully in his Christmas stocking?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —This issue received some coverage at our Estimates committee. I forget whether it was Senator Newman or Senator MacGibbon who raised it, but certainly one of Senator Chapman's colleagues was kind enough to raise it there as well. At the Estimates committee-and I will make sure that a transcript of the proceedings is provided to the honourable senator-it was discovered that this was no ordinary soldier, but a big lad and getting bigger all the time. As I understand it, it is not possible, with our normal makers of uniforms, to find someone to make a uniform quite that big. Special arrangements were having to be made for this particular soldier.

ANSWER.PARA: I immediately referred this matter, in accordance with my undertaking, to the Minister for Defence, but we have run into a problem because of this person's extraordinary size. I will check on when the uniform will be ready, but I know that the Department of Defence is making giant strides to help this soldier.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Finance explain the role of inflation adjustment in the Government's family policies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think everybody understands that indexation means that the real value of a payment is maintained over time. Many payments have been indexed for a number of years. For example, the age pension was first indexed in 1976. This year the Government made a decision for the first time ever to index virtually all social security payments and, most importantly, to index payments to families with children. Although such payments were not formally indexed in the past, since this Government has been in office such payments have been substantially increased in real terms, even though there was no formal indexation. For example, under the family assistance system, or the family assistance scheme, as we call it, in 1983 the payments per child were increased from $15 to $17; in 1984, to $19; in 1985, to $21; in 1986, from $21 to $22; in 1987, a very major increase from $22 to $27 for children under 13 and to $33 for children aged 13 and above; in 1988, the payments increased from $27 to $29 and $36 respectively; and this year the payments increased to $33 and $43 respectively, achieving the benchmark that the Government had set some years ago of payments equal to 15 and 20 per cent of the married rate pension.

ANSWER.PARA: Since all those payments have been formally indexed, their value in real terms is guaranteed until such time as some government changes the legislation. The importance of indexation was recognised very clearly by Senator Chaney in 1976 when he said:
These adjustments-
and that adjustment was the indexation of the age pension to which I referred earlier-
do not depend upon the good will or the ill will of politicians. They will be automatic. This is an historical first in this country.

It is a pity that Senator Chaney did not deliver for Australian families when he was Minister for Social Security the same protection against erosion of real value that the Fraser Government, to its credit, delivered to age pensioners in 1976. I suppose it is even more of a pity that Senator Chaney continues not to recognise the importance of indexation of family payments. Indeed, it is very difficult to establish just what the Opposition's position is on this. Yesterday Senator Chaney said:
That all stands. That is a clear position. It has not changed in the statement.
That was in respect of family payments. On Tuesday, Mr Connolly, who was speaking on his own portfolio area for a change, said:
As with other pensions and benefits, the coalition supports their payment to families and their indexation.

But if we look at this morning's Sydney Morning Herald we discover that the Leader of the Opposition has clarified the Opposition's policy on indexation and made it clear that there is no commitment to index family allowances at all. The Opposition says that it believes in competition, variety and freedom of choice. It has certainly given the electors some freedom of choice. The electors can choose whichever one of the three mutually inconsistent policies that the Opposition has put up on this matter, among many others.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. Has his attention been drawn to a report attributed to John Hallows in the Sunday Telegraph last week that the cost of annuities will inevitably rise because of the needs for fund managers to limit their annuity commitments due to the expected enormous growth in demand caused by Government policy changes? Does not the author's assertion `that the likely increase in the cost of annuities could get to the point that the promised tax benefits no longer balance the cost of buying them' mean that recent policy changes in superannuation, therefore, as introduced by the Government in the August Budget, are not worth a cracker?

—The Sunday Telegraph is not a paper that I normally read. I think I probably show good judgment in not doing that. I have not seen the article and therefore cannot give any detailed response to the question. If I heard Senator Messner correctly, he said, quoting the author of that article, that the cost of annuities would increase because the demand for annuities would go up. Frankly, that seems to me to be an assertion which is unlikely to be correct. As for the rest of the question, I will have to get Senator Messner a response from the Minister.

—I ask the Minister for Resources, with, I confess, a considerable degree of satisfaction, whether he can advise the Senate of the implications for Australia, and in particular the Northern Territory, of the successful conclusion of negotiations between the Australian and Indonesian governments on the cooperative arrangements on exploiting the petroleum resources of the Timor Gap.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —While the question is directed to me, I should acknowledge that the lead Minister is the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans. He and his counterpart from Indonesia, Mr Alatas, have set the framework for these negotiations. I am pleased to acknowledge that my role has been represented on the Indonesian side by the Minister for Mines and Energy, Mr Ginandjar. The detail of how the framework set by Senator Evans and his counterpart, Mr Alatas, is to be filled in for the exploration industry has fallen to us.

ANSWER.PARA: As Senator Collins said, it is true that today Senator Evans and I had a joint press conference in which we announced the successful outcome of what has been a year-long round of negotiation between Australia and Indonesia to conclude a treaty on the exploitation of the Timor Gap-or, as it is properly called, the Zone of Cooperation Agreement between Australia and Indonesia on the Timor Gap.

TALK.START.PARA: —It takes BHP longer to get a decision out of the Government.

—The Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd may well be a beneficiary because it is a company that has an aggressive exploration policy in the Timor Sea. The main aspect of the agreement that relates to the question I have been asked is that it does delimit the area into three zones: a joint zone, zone A, between Australia and Indonesia, an Australian zone B, and an Indonesian zone C. It sets down a mining regime for both countries. It sets down a production sharing formula as well. It provides details for company and personal tax arrangements, details for employment conditions and details on how prior claims will be met.

ANSWER.PARA: The part relevant to the Northern Territory is that, as well, it provides for the administrative arrangements to oversee the operations in this area through a ministerial council with a joint authority to carry out its work. The headquarters of the joint authority will be located in Jakarta, but the technical directorate for the joint authority will be located in Darwin. Initially for Darwin that will mean some staffing, some location of equipment and some office space being taken in that city for the operations of this joint authority. Later next year I hope that the ministerial council and the authority can work to achieve a situation in which the joint governments announce a program of releases of offshore acreage for exploration purposes and invite companies to bid for the rights to explore in those areas. If that is the case, Darwin is located ideally for it to be a staging ground for a lot of offshore activity for oil explorers in the Timor Sea. Already it is the location of the major Australian Timor Sea exploration and production effort.

In zone A, the area that is jointly regulated by Indonesia and Australia, the main geological feature is a formation known as the Kelp structure. Many exploration experts have speculated that it may contain up to one billion barrels of oil. It could be oil; it could be gas; it could be sea water; but it is a very promising exploration target. I expect there to be very stiff competition between potential explorers for the rights to explore in that region. Zone B, the Australian area, is on the continental shelf and that too is an area of very high prospectivity.

If, following the exploration effort, there are significant discoveries, Darwin and the Northern Territory stand to benefit again as the potential staging post for the whole of the production operation. Therefore, this agreement, significant as it is between Australia and Indonesia for a host of reasons, some of which Senator Evans referred to in his statement today, is significant for the Northern Territory too for industry reasons. I add for the benefit of Senator Collins that, because of that, I notified the Minister for Mines and Energy in the Northern Territory, Mr Barry Coulter, of this this morning.
Sitting suspended from 12.57 to 2 p.m.

The addendum to the Minister's answer, in which she says that she would like to take the opportunity to point out that Australia is sending an all-women delegation is wrong in fact. It is also opportunistic of her--
