—The implication by the Minister that somehow the composition of the delegation has something to do with the fact that the senators are female is completely erroneous. I find it offensive because we on this side of the House have been chosen on merit. I cannot say the same for the Minister.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The President has received a letter from Senator Short proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Hawke Government's misuse of the taxpayer-funded National Media Liaison Service for blatant party political purposes in ALP State election campaigns.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition I propose that the following matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion:

SPEECH.PARA: The Hawke Government's misuse of the taxpayer-funded National Media Liaison Service for blatant party political purposes in ALP State election campaigns.

The Opposition is raising this matter today because it is of considerable importance for at least two reasons. The first is that it exposes the Queensland branch of the Australian Labor Party for what it is. It is a party which, even in opposition-and it is going to stay in opposition for a long time-seeks to drink from the taxpayers' cup through its discredited, dishonoured and dishonourable Federal big brother, the Hawke Labor Government in Canberra. The Hawke Government has mercilessly, brutally and deliberately bled Australian taxpayers to death during its seven years in government. On top of that, it has produced an economic crisis in Australia virtually without precedent. The second reason why the debate is important is that it exposes once and for all the totally political nature of the Hawke Government's so-called National Media Liaison Service, the NMLS, better known as `aNiMaLS'. It could be more accurately described as the Government's thought police.

In the run-up to the forthcoming Queensland election, the Leader of the Labor Party in Queensland, Mr Goss, has been presenting himself as Mr `nice guy' and Mr `clean skin'. He has been sanctimoniously holding up himself and the Queensland branch of the Australian Labor Party as paragons of virtue in a sea of problems. We now know-we have proof positive-that the claims are a sanctimonious, hypocritical sham.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish you would get to the point and not the hyperbole.

—I will come to that. Mr Goss and the Queensland Labor Party are once again trying to put Labor's nose in the taxpayers' purse. At Question Time this morning, Senator Parer-I am sorry that he is unable to be here this afternoon to hear this debate but he is unable to attend for logistic reasons associated with the pilots dispute-asked the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, to assure the Senate that the National Media Liaison Service offices have not been and will not be used by any Federal Minister or ministerial office specifically to assist Labor Party candidates in State elections in South Australia or Queensland. He also asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Would the Minister agree that the use of the National Media Liaison Service for State election campaigns would be a gross abuse of the role of the National Media Liaison Service?
The Minister did not muck around in his answer. He said:
The National Media Liaison Service will not have a role in the Queensland and South Australian elections, neither should it.

That is something that we on this side of the chamber totally agree with. The only problem is that in the very next moment the Minister was shot down in flames when Senator Parer incorporated in Hansard a letter from the office of one of the Federal Government's most senior Ministers, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you actually read the letter?

—Yes, I have, and I will read it again. The letter was addressed to Mr Joe Begley of the Opposition Leader's office in Queensland, and a copy of it was sent to `aNiMaLS' offices in Brisbane and Townsville. The letter stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Joe
Naturally this office stands ready to assist wherever possible during the State election campaign.
I'd like to offer my services in dealing with any Federal issues in the agriculture, mining, rural and provincial affairs areas which I have no doubt will be raised during the campaign.
Candidates should direct any cuttings of Federal criticism . . .
A telephone and a fax number were provided for a direct reply. The letter continued:
I would be obliged if you could pass this advice on to all candidates and sitting members.
I will also seek expanded monitoring of such issues from NMLS offices in Brisbane and Townsville.
Senator Richardson was then asked a supplementary question by Senator Parer and in response to that he stated:

Like Mr Kerin, I will be most concerned to see during the course of not just the Queensland but the South Australian election as well that outrageous claims made about Commonwealth policy are answered. Because that tends to be the order of the day in election campaigns, I, too, will make sure that those States are well and truly monitored. Where statements are made that are outrageous, I will also make sure they are corrected. That is the proper role for the National Media Liaison Service. It is not a role in the campaign.

That answer contains absolute nonsense. It contains a complete lack of knowledge or a wilful misunderstanding and interpretation of the stated role of the directives issued by the Minister himself as to the functions of the NMLS. Amongst other things the Minister's directives to the NMLS as to what it is all about-this is the fourth point-says:
Representatives will not work with local or State Party Branches and will not be involved in Party programs nor electoral campaigning.

It is simply not possible to interpret that function, that directive, to the NMLS in terms of what it shall or shall not do to enable it to play the role that is being envisaged for it by Mr Kerin's office. It says that representatives-I repeat this-will not work with local or State branches and will not be involved in party programs nor in electoral campaigning. Absolutely totally what Mr Kerin's office is offering Mr Goss's office is assistance in State electoral campaigning. There is no other way in which that can possibly be interpreted. That is not really surprising because the whole history of the NMLS, the `aNiMaLS', since this Government came to office and established aNiMaLS, in 1983, has been to turn it progressively into a blatant political party organisation at taxpayers' expense.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?

—It is difficult to get exact figures because the figures are hidden in the books. The books are cooked because the real cost of running the NMLS is scattered around a whole range of government accounts. On any conservative estimate the cost to taxpayers of this party political propaganda machine that masquerades under a government unit has to be in excess of $12m over the last five years. It is increasing at an escalating rate. It is interesting that when the NMLS was set up by Mr Young, under his responsibility as Special Minister of State, on 25 May 1983 in the House of Representatives in establishing it he said:

SPEECH.PARA: NMLS will work for the Government, not the Australian Labor Party.

Prior to the 1987 election, after the 1984 election, this unit was transferred to the wing of the then Arts, Sport and Tourism Minister-a great place to put the NMLS. That was John Brown's portfolio. It went there because John Brown was a political heavyweight. He had the political nose. Honourable senators should look at what has happened to John Brown. He certainly had a nose. Paul Kelly gave the reasons for this change in an article in the Australian on 22 September last year. Kelly said that the change was made because the unit was seen to be ineffective in the 1984 Federal election. He said that Mr Brown took it over and gave it a political thrust. When it had done its work after the 1987 election, very effectively I must say-I believe there is a reasonable argument to mount that the 1987 election was won for the Government by `aNiMaLS'-it went back to the Minister for Administrative Services.

In the run-up to the next election it has gone back to Senator Richardson-the numbers man of the ALP, the wheeler and dealer of the ALP, the complete political animal, the Minister for truth and, as so aptly described recently in the Sydney Morning Herald, the keeper of the `aNiMaLS'. That change back to Senator Richardson was made without any public announcement at all. It is extraordinary that at the beginning of 1989 when this transfer was made back to Senator Richardson the National Media Liaison Service, the disseminator of government information, did not put out a press statement. There was no statement made at all of that transfer. In the Estimates committee hearing just three or four months earlier, when I quoted a Sydney Morning Herald report that the transfer would be made to Senator Richardson, Senator Ray, the Minister at the table at the time, rubbished me and said that I should not listen to every ragbag news report that I get. Three or four months later it has gone exactly the way it had been predicted.

The Opposition's concern with the operations of the NMLS has been well documented over a lengthy period. Many members of the Opposition-Senator Baume, Senator Messner, I and many others-have pointed attention increasingly to the overt political nature of this organisation. The first guideline of the National Media Liaison Service, as laid down by the relevant Minister of the day-now Senator Richardson-says that its role is to provide accurate and timely information on government policies and programs to the media throughout Australia as well as information on policies to interest groups within electorates. I repeat that: to provide accurate and timely information on government policies and programs. Michelle Grattan, in a notable speech last December in terms of the operations of the Government in the media area, amongst other things, said:

More controversial on the propaganda front is the work of the NMLS. It is a questionable use of taxpayers' money because it is totally political. One of the more extraordinary features about it is that perhaps 80 per cent of the transcripts it has put out publicly this year are not from government Ministers but from the Opposition. It is the Ministry of the Opposition.

The Director of the NMLS, Colin Parks, was questioned before the Estimates Committee three weeks ago about the role of `aNiMaLs'. He was asked specifically to comment, and to quantify the degree of dissemination of opposition material as distinct from government material, that was made. He was not prepared to either agree or disagree with Michelle Grattan's estimate that 80 per cent of the work of the unit, in terms of the transcripts put around, was involved with Opposition material. That is an extraordinary situation for the director of the Government's unit to be in. He is the person who is in charge. He is the person who directs the activities of the unit. He is the person who wears two hats. He is not only the Director of the National Media Liaison Service but also the Director of the Ministerial Media Group. When questioned as to his political activities he said that as a director of the NMLS he does not do anything political. What he, in effect, does is put on his Ministerial Media Group hat. The role of the Ministerial Media Group and of the leader of that group is to provide advice to the Government, which obviously would be of a political nature. There is a con, a confusion and blurring of lines there at great cost to the taxpayers. It is a dishonest attempt by the Government to disguise the activities of the director of the Media Liaison Service.

The Service is supposed to provide, according to the guidelines, information to members of parliament and senators. There is nothing in the guidelines to suggest that there be a discrimination between Government members and senators and Opposition members and senators. Indeed, on 21 September this year in a television interview when the Minister, Senator Richardson, was asked whether there was discrimination, he said that he was not aware of anyone ever having been denied access to a transcript. He was wrong. It was only in the Estimates Committee three weeks later that the Director of the NMLS, Colin Parks, agreed that there had been a long-standing decision not to service Opposition members and senators. That was absolutely contrary to what Senator Richardson had told millions of viewers on television on 21 September. Because he had made that mistake and had misinformed-I will not use a stronger term-television viewers as to the breadth of coverage of the NMLS he subsequently, and, conveniently, just before the Estimates Committee met, issued a directive instructing Mr Parks that in future he was to supply transcripts to all members and senators on request. The activities of the NMLS in terms of servicing and dissemination of information to members of parliament have, from its inception until three weeks ago, been absolutely contrary and discriminatory in relation to its guidelines.

I return to the question of the role that the NMLS and the Federal Government will play in the State election in Queensland. It is not just a matter of the services of the NMLS; there will be the full blast of the Ministerial Media Group. No doubt there will be full use of the 60 or more consultants who, over the last year or so, have been in the paid employ of Government Ministers at a cost to the taxpayer well in excess of $2m. The use of consultants is to get around the so-called guidelines on staffing in the Public Service and ministerial offices, and the cost of consultants has increased fivefold in the last four years. When we add that to the $12m-plus cost of the NMLS and the uncosted additional amounts of the Ministerial Media Group, we get a huge body of apparatchiks doing nothing but support, at public expense, the blatant political activities of the Government.

Of course, a government, or any political party, has to be political. It would not exist if it were not. But it is wrong and disgraceful that any political party should undertake all its political activities at the taxpayers' expense. This Government has done that since the day it came in. It has been bleeding the taxpayers of this country dry. It will use its ministry of truth unit to play a role in the forthcoming Queensland election campaign-I will bet my bottom dollar that it will do exactly the same in the South Australian campaign-in a way that I believe every Australian would be outraged about.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the reasons why so many politicians are held in low esteem is the belief by ordinary citizens that hypocrisy and humbug rule the day. The sad thing about today's debate is that if any of those taxpayers out there are unfortunate enough to be listening they will realise that once again another politician has chosen to get up and speak only from pure hypocrisy. There is nothing impure about it; I will say that. It is pure and it is perfect.

SPEECH.PARA: Almost the last words used by Senator Short in his contribution concerned the Government `bleeding the taxpayers of this country dry' by the activities of the National Media Liaison Service. If Senator Short or any of his colleagues were really serious about eliminating any suggestion of political expenditure from taxpayers' pockets they were right to concentrate on Queensland but wrong to debate the matter in the way they have. Whatever happened to any sort of careful analysis of the behaviour of the Queensland Government? If someone happens to be in Queensland just before the 6 o'clock news on Sunday night and watches any one of three commercial television stations he will see a five-minute program paid for by the Queensland Government called Queensland 2000. It is no coincidence that for the last five weeks Ministers in marginal seats have been featured on Queensland 2000. Since Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen left office-and we all thought he had elevated this to an art form-Ahern and then Cooper have managed to spend $25m on paid Government political advertising.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I believe that the Minister has strayed far and wide from the motion before us. He has moved on to State matters. State matters have absolutely no relevance to the motion before us.

—Order! There is no point of order. The motion moved by Senator Short refers to the use of a taxpayer-funded organisation for blatant party political purposes in State election campaigns. Senator Richardson should come back to the motion directly before us but at the moment his remarks are in order.

—The two Premiers who have succeeded Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen have spent $25m in two years. No government in the country has come close to that. No other government in the country would have the gall to attempt it. But today Senator Short is making a pathetic attempt to have a go at an organisation that costs $1m per year in pursuit of legitimate Government activity while totally ignoring a corrupt and horrible regime in Queensland which wastes taxpayers' dollars hand over fist every single day of every single year.
—What about Neville Wran?
—Neville Wran would never have attempted a program like Queensland 2000 and Senator McGauran knows it. I know he has not been around very long but not even he could be obtuse enough not to know that.
—He could be.

—Senator McMullan might be right once again; he could be. Let us get it straight about today's matter of public importance. It is not so much an attack on the National Media Liaison Service (NMLS) as a desperate attempt by this Opposition to divert some more attention from the horrible week it has had. And it has been horrible. Shadow Minister after shadow Minister has bitten the dust. Let us ask Mr Braithwaite and Dr Hewson what sort of a week they have had. Let us ask Mr Connolly what sort of a week he has had. They have had a rotten week-and I understand that-but they ought to be used to it by now. They ought to be accustomed to it. The difficulty is, of course, that every time the Opposition goes through one of these bad weeks and the National Media Liaison Service, as part of its legitimate role, highlights one of these incredible gaffes and the gallery write about it, and the Opposition says once again, `Let's shoot the messenger'. But it cannot keep shooting the messengers. Members of the Opposition have to stop shooting themselves. They have the most shot-off feet in Australian political history.

SPEECH.PARA: I notice that Senator Michael Baume is going to speak in this debate. He is a past master. His efforts during the 1987 election campaign were a far greater contribution to Labor's victory than anything the National Media Liaison Service could ever have contemplated. To this day we remain grateful to Senator Michael Baume.

The National Media Liaison Service is not a new organisation. It is not a new idea. Senator Short talked about Mr Young establishing it in 1983, but all Mr Young did was rename an organisation which was formed under the Fraser Government, when it was called the Government Information Unit (GIU). The real crime of the National Media Liaison Service in Senator Short's eyes is that, unlike the Government Information Unit, it is efficient and effective. Of course, that is another reason for this attack-it is because it does such a good job that it causes so much irritation.

Let us look at the historical record. Let us see what we inherited as a government-the notorious forerunner of the National Media Liaison Service, the Government Information Unit. I want to draw on some documents, documents which can be on the public record, to show just how hypocritical this whole debate is. The Senate will realise that normally governments do not have access to the confidential records of their predecessors-and neither should they-but the Government Information Unit could not even manage to shred the files when the Fraser Government was thrown out in 1983. Two manila folders survived for posterity, and I am glad that they did.

The first document I want to refer to is stamped `Confidential'. It is dated December 1978 and appears to be the extract of a Cabinet document. I am happy to table a copy of that document for the record. It reports a proposal to appoint liaison officers in the State capitals following a report from the GIU that the media in the States was unusually susceptible-a great phrase-to anti-Canberra and anti-government stories. The paper set out the functions of those liaison officers for this forerunner of the National Media Liaison Service. I want to quote to the Senate exactly what `his' role was-there being no suggestion, of course, that there could have been a `her' in there, in the male chauvinistic environment in which the Fraser Government lived. The document states:
- To report regularly on significant State issues which have or could have relevance to the Government.
- To disseminate effectively Government information in his State.
- To liaise and communicate with Ministers and Members, State and Federal; Division Officers; Media; Special Interest Groups.
All that is fine-how could we complain?-but let me read the next paragraph:
- To monitor, analyse and report on television and radio current affairs and comment programs as they affect the Commonwealth Government in any way.

That is exactly what the National Media Liaison Service does now. There were no complaints from Senator Short or Senator Michael Baume, who were members of the Fraser Government, about the Government Information Unit. One can search Hansard all day and night, but one will not find any complaints from them. They were very happy to have a government body doing exactly what the present one does. The document goes further:
- To undertake responsibility for arrangements for Ministerial visits to the State concerned to ensure best media coverage and full use of a Minister's time.

Again, the National Media Liaison Service officers are occasionally involved in that practice. They certainly do not have responsibility for itineraries, but help out where they can. It is the next sentence which shows the difference in character of the Government Information Unit of the Liberal-National Party Government from that of the National Media Liaison Service now. It states:
- To maintain close contact with party officials in the State, keeping them fully informed of developments on the Federal scene.
I repeat, `close contact with party officials in the State'.

The sad thing for the hypocrites who want to build something out of this debate is that nowhere in our literature, nowhere in the records of campaign meetings of the Australian Labor Party, will they find anything about National Media Liaison Service officers keeping Party officials fully informed. Their roles are separate. They are not permitted to do that. But the Fraser Government permitted an organisation to do it directly and deliberately, and that is what condemns Senator Short today. The Labor Party has no record of any close contact with GIU officers; the Australian Democrats have no record of close contact with GIU officers; so to which Party was this document referring? It was the Liberal Party of Australia, and it may have been the National Party of Australia. That was a truly disgraceful use of taxpayers' money and one that I, as the Minister responsible, simply will not permit.

These so-called liaison officers in the GIU were to be appointed, at taxpayers' expense, to work for the Liberal Party. That is not just an allegation, because the fact that they did so was documented just three years later, on 8 April 1981, when the Labor Party had incorporated in Hansard some documents leaked from the Liberal Party. I want to table those documents. There is no need to keep them secret, after all, because the Liberal Party was never secretive about the use of Government money for its own election campaigns. One document, a media guide, states:
This modest `Media Guide' simply provides some useful hints on obtaining local coverage and on maintaining a mutually beneficial relationship with the media.
For the seasoned campaigner, the guide may serve as a handy `checklist'.

What it did not say is that, for the seasoned rorter, it showed the way to use Government money for political purposes. Unfortunately, the Government of the day allowed GIU staff to attend election campaign planning meetings, and that is where Senator Short stands condemned because, when that was going on, he had nothing whatsoever to say about it. There is no record of any member of the Fraser Government at any time raising the slightest query about this use of taxpayers' funds-a use which I have said I, as the Minister, would simply not permit because it is wrong.

It is clear from the documents which I have tabled that the GIU had a key role in the Liberal Party campaign apparatus. If one looks at how far it went, one realises that the Fraser Government-of which Senator Short and Senator Michael Baume were members-had no shame whatsoever. Not only was the GIU used to campaign against other political parties, but it also ran the personal vendettas of the Prime Minister. I remember a certain Minister resigning because, he said, Mr Fraser had a manic obsession to get his own way. Honourable senators opposite may remember that person. His name is Andrew Peacock. The problem for Mr Peacock was that, within seconds of his making that now-famous speech at a press conference, Malcolm Fraser was listening to a GIU-provided tape of what Mr Peacock had had to say. That Government not only blatantly-to use the word in the Opposition's own motion-used the GIU against its political opponents, but also used it against members of its own Party. There can be no more disgraceful use of taxpayers' money than that which took place while the Government Information Unit existed. Some background notes on current issues for candidates dated May 1981 really told it all. Russell Schneider, a former Fraser Government press secretary, became a journalist and wrote in the Weekend Australian on 14 March 1981 as follows:

The Unit (the Government Information Unit) became a handy off-shoot of the Liberal Party at last year's election campaign, being able to monitor news broadcasts and help Ministers arrange their programs.

The Labor Party remembers that because of what the GIU did in relation to capital gains tax during the 1980 election campaign. There was no doubt about where the GIU stood and what it was being used for, but all we got from the Liberal Party was silence. There was not a word-not a syllable-uttered against that disgraceful use of public money.

It gets worse. We have heard talk today about bleeding the taxpayer dry, about how much the National Media Liaison Service costs. Let us look at the costs. The GIU's budget for 1982-83, seven years ago, was $1.4m. The National Media Liaison Service spent less than $1.2m in 1988-89. Six or seven years later it could not spend as much as its predecessor had spent. That is how disgraceful that operation was.

TALK.START.PARA: —You know your figure is grossly understated.

—It is not grossly understated; it is exact. It is right through the Estimates. Senator Short knows that it is exact. How dare he challenge that figure. No-one can challenge that figure. As I said earlier, the Government Information Unit was notorious. It was a disgrace, and it never stopped being one. No Minister in the Fraser Government ever took the slightest interest in making sure that it behaved with propriety. As I have said, no-one could testify better on that point than Andrew Peacock.

SPEECH.PARA: On 11 November 1982 the Senate was told of yet another Government Information Unit document. This time, the Government Information Unit was not harassing the Labor Party or spying on its own members. No, it had gone further; it had found yet another function. This function was to harass interviewers to make sure that they were put off during their attempts to interview Government members. Of course, it referred to Derryn Hinch. The advice was to distract his producer or his researcher outside while the interview was being conducted so that no notes could be passed on to poor Derryn. Of course, this does not say much for Mr Hinch. I want to defend him. I cannot imagine why the Government Information Unit would have such a low regard for him. But that is what happened.

It also makes one wonder what the Unit thought of the Government Ministers being interviewed by Mr Hinch; how hopeless it must have thought they were. There it was again in black and white: how to distract the interviewer. That is the sort of puerile nonsense that this Unit carried on with. That does not happen today, and as long as I am the responsible Minister I will make sure that it does not happen. There is no doubt that the Government Information Unit spent much of its time monitoring what was said about Government policies. I and the Government can have no query whatsoever about that. That is a legitimate role for such a unit. It is a legitimate and necessary function of that kind of organisation. Governments obviously have to know about criticisms and misinformation campaigns so that they can respond to them. That is what the National Media Liaison Service now does. It monitors, transcribes and analyses criticisms of the Government.

It is no secret that most of that criticism will come from the Opposition. Because the job has been done efficiently for so long, Opposition members have finally learned how much damage it is doing them. I suggest to Senator Short, Senator Michael Baume, Senator Messner and anyone else in the Opposition that, if they were to perform properly, they would not have a problem. The only thing that has been exposed today is their terror of their inability. They cannot perform; they cannot get their act together; none of them knows where the others stand; and they are caught out on an hourly basis. As they say in the classics: that is tough cheese. It will keep happening as long as this Opposition cannot fire. The National Media Liaison Service will continue its role and Opposition members will continue to suffer as long as the quality of their performance is as it has been today. That will not make its role illegitimate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Richardson has just given one of his typical, but more ludicrous speeches. Anyone listening to what he said will, I presume, now be totally convinced of the merit of the Opposition's case against both him, as the Minister in charge, and the National Media Liaison Service (NMLS), which has now become a clear and blatant political instrument of this Government paid for by the people of Australia. It is a political instrument not simply of this Government but of any Labor Party government in any State in Australia that happens to be in an election environment. How do we know that? We see it from the letter which was tabled in this place today as part of a question asked by Senator Parer from Queensland. He simply asked whether `aNiMaLS' would be involved in the Queensland campaign. The Minister replied:

SPEECH.PARA: The National Media Liaison Service will not have a role in the Queensland and South Australian elections, neither should it.

When he then heard the contents of the letter, he gave the most nonsensical, dissembling reply, in which he said that, of course, it will be monitoring what people say about Commonwealth policy in these elections because in an election campaign `that tends to be the order of the day'. He continued:
I, too, will make sure that those States are well and truly monitored. Where statements are made that are outrageous, I will also make sure that they are corrected.

I draw the attention of Senator Richardson to the text of the letter from the office of Mr John Kerin, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and one of the outstandingly honest members of this Government, as can be seen by the fact that he is always in total conflict with his colleagues, and is at the moment. Mr Kerin's office has written to the office of the Queensland Opposition Leader, Mr Goss. The letter states, `I will also seek expanded monitoring' Not just monitoring. I give honourable senators the key words: `Because there is an election campaign I will seek expanded monitoring'. Can there by anything clearer than that? This is a political response to a political situation at the public's cost, because the people involved are employed at the cost of the taxpayers. They are to participate in an expanded monitoring of such issues-for no other reason than that there is an election campaign on in Queensland. That is in the letter. It is not the normal monitoring that goes on out of the Townsville spying office or the Brisbane spying office, the propaganda office, the Goebbels office in those centres; this is expanded for one reason only-and it is clear-because there is an election campaign. Yet this Minister got up here and quite happily said, `Nothing like that would happen. I would not respond and take part in a State election campaign'. He is condemned because of this letter. What is worse is that there was not one word of apology from this Minister for misleading this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not misled it.

—If the Minister had been listening instead of gossiping and chatting to the next speaker in the debate, he would have heard that the word `expanded' clearly demolishes whatever moral position he desperately tried to create. There is no admission about his misleading behaviour here. There is no embarrassment about involving more and more--
—None at all.

—He has no shame whatsoever. It is simple: the Minister has attempted to suggest that all this is exactly what happened under the previous Government. That is absolute bunkum. We can see that in the doubling of the number of propaganda operatives employed by this Government as against the previous Government. It is not just the National Media Liaison Service; it is the Ministerial Media Group; it is the journalists employed in ministerial offices.
—And the consultants.

—And the consultants, as Senator Short says. This massive propaganda machine costs multimillions of dollars more than the $1.3m revealed as the cost of the National Media Liaison Service, which makes up only a fraction of this Government's propaganda operation.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Minister is unaware of them, I will quickly go through another response to a question about the number of press people around. For example, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has one adviser press secretary but many other press people. The Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis): one journalist. The Treasurer (Mr Keating): one journalist. The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh): one journalist. The Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris): one journalist. That goes on for pages in the document I have. Each Minister has his own little propaganda operation. This Minister pretends that this is the same as happened under Fraser.

Let me tell honourable senators that I think there were five press secretaries under the Fraser Government. That Government created the Government Information Unit (GIU) to make up for the fact that Ministers did not have their own press secretaries. The Minister knows that but he seeks to come in here and to deceive this place by pretending that `aNiMaLS' is exactly the same as the GIU was under Fraser. What absolute nonsense! How much are people in `aNiMaLS' getting? They must be very good. They are being paid as much as a member of Parliament. These journos who are trying to destroy the Opposition, who are acting in a political way, are being paid exactly the same as a politician. I suppose that is only fair because they are acting as political animals.

The Minister clearly knows as little about what the journalists are getting as he knows about what they are doing. Their pay is $54,691 including the $9,104 per annum payable in addition to salary to occupants of these positions. On top of that Mr Parks gets about $62,000, as I recall it. That is what Mr Parks gets-Mr Parks who manages to operate at election time; the man who runs this non-political operation. According to the Minister, `I would not let someone run a political operation'. Mr Parks who runs that operation at election times operates out of the campaign headquarters of the Australian Labor Party. The Minister cannot deny that. He just says, `He is wearing a different hat when he operates'. It is absolutely incredible.

TALK.START.PARA: —He remains head of `aNiMaLS'.

—As my colleague says, Mr Parks who operates as a political propagandising adviser to the Government, who is deeply involved in political campaigning, continues as Director of `aNiMaLS' during an election campaign.

SPEECH.PARA: We have a clear situation where there has been this massive build-up in the number of people and the cost to the public of a propaganda operation funded at considerable expense and doing far more-in a far more devious way, I might say-than can ever be claimed was the activity of the previous organisation. Let me deal very quickly with this point. As the Minister said-he tabled some documents-there have been some discussions in the past about what was the role of the Fraser Government's group. I can remember Mr Dawkins and Mr Duffy in 1981 thumping their breasts and saying how disgraceful it was that there was a Government Information Unit. Mr Duffy in the House of Representatives said about the Government:
It will learn that the people of Australia will not, and should not, tolerate public servants being used as part of the Liberal Party machine.

Is it not incredible how the morality suddenly changes when those opposite get their snouts in the trough? Is it not also incredible that those opposite allege that the documents that were tabled show a massive GIU involvement in political activity under the Fraser Government? Let me tell honourable senators what that was. I had a look at the documents, unlike the Minister who just threw them around--

TALK.START.PARA: —I tabled them.
—He tabled them. Let me tell exactly what the involvement was in those documents which were tabled on 8 April 1981. This GIU `involvement' with the election campaign was:

SPEECH.PARA: FOLLOW-UP ACTION
Dale:
To speak to Vince Matthews about the GIU relaying all press releases and AAP reports to the travelling team.
That is monitoring--

TALK.START.PARA: —That's it exactly.

—That is exactly the same as this mob is doing. This is the monitoring role: relaying all press releases and Australian Associated Press reports to the travelling team. How different is that from the monitoring role of Senator Richardson's group of propagandists who not only monitor the media direct on a politically selective basis but also disseminate that information to the press gallery? We will go into that later. To pretend that the GIU whose monitoring role was exactly as I have outlined it here-honourable senators may have some arguments about its other role, about the fact that some GIU people sat in on meetings-was doing nothing like what the Minister is now encouraging and paying with taxpayers' money the National Media Liaison Service to undertake is nonsense. To pretend otherwise is deliberate nonsense and is done with the intention of misleading the people of Australia about the way in which their money is being used in this disgraceful way. I am not the only one who is saying that. The whole of the press gallery has been aware of this massive change in the role--
—Have a read of Laurie Oakes in the Bulletin.

—I have read Laurie Oakes and I wonder who provided him with the material. Perhaps the Minister might let us know where he got it. I spoke today to Mr Newman, the Minister who was in charge of the GIU. I got a total assurance from him which I believe to be true because there is no evidence to counter it. This Minister has not presented any in his speech today. Mr Newman advised me that under him the GIU provided no analysis or reactions to Opposition statements which the National Media Liaison Service does, not only for the Minister but also for the press gallery. The GIU had no role in State election campaigns.

—It never ever put out transcripts of Opposition statements; never, ever. Just look at the difference between the role of the GIU then and the role of the current organisation. SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that the National Media Liaison Service will participate, and it is being instructed by this Government to participate, in a State election campaign. The aNiMaLS do a very efficient, I would even say at times, ruthless job-
because of this monitoring role that it goes on with-

but you try and get a transcript out of them that when a Government Minister drops a clanger, `Oh', says Colin Parks, the director of the aNiMaLS, `I don't think we monitored that'. They monitored it all right . . .
So said Bowers I continue:
It just doesn't suit them to put it out.

I will not say that Peter Bowers is a journalist to be dismissed or disregarded. He is only one of the many who have commented. I have pages and pages of journalistic comments--

SPEECH.PARA: I was not in the House of Representatives between 1975 and 1983. I would love to have been there when Mr Short, as he then was, and Mr Michael Baume, as he then was, got up and said, `We have received this terrible transcript from the GIU'. They tore it up and said, `Never bring this to us again. This is a misuse of taxpayers' funds. We are shocked and appalled'. They attacked the Fraser Government. They said, `Tear it up and put in a brown paper bag'. It might even have been the sort of brown paper bag that Sir Joh thought he was receiving. They would never have tolerated such a thing.

I am actually thinking of dismissing my research officer to whom I said, `Go through the Hansards. Find all the times that they spoke about it'. He said, `There were not any'. I thought: that cannot be right; these honourable men would not have said something today and nothing seven or eight years ago. These are people who are outraged. These are people of consistent moral uprightness. They would have been concerned; they would have spoken out'. But actually I think my research officer was right, that in all those years they never said a word. They sat there mute and indolent hoping that nobody would find out.

The voters might not have found out about the Government Information Unit (GIU) but they certainly found out about Messrs Short and Baume. That is why they are here now-they were kicked out very quickly from the other place. What are they actually complaining about? What is their complaint in terms of the national role of the National Media Liaison Service (NMLS)? They are not saying that the NMLS tells lies about us. They are saying the NMLS tells the truth about us. People find out what we have actually said. There has not been one occasion on which anybody has said that the NMLS has misinformed people about the comments made by shadow Ministers. They are saying that the NMLS accurately informed people about what we had said.

I do not blame some people for being outraged about having the truth told about them. This can be very embarrassing and it has been very embarrassing from time to time for some of the participants in this debate. I understand that, but this is really not the basis for confected moral outrage. If one stands up in public and says that certain things ought not to be done, one is going to be judged by what one has done in the past. The two people who have already spoken in this debate and Senator Messner, who will speak after me, were beneficiaries of the Government Information Unit in its legitimate activities and, I am quite certain, in its illegitimate activities.

What on earth is happening? Are Senator Baume and Senator Short saying that no government should monitor what people say about it? There are two reasons that every government since the advent of newspapers and particularly since the invention of the tape recorder has endeavoured to monitor what people say about it. I accept that one of them is a partisan reason and that everybody does it-that is, we need to find out what people are saying about us so that we can respond. But we also need to find out what people are saying about us because sometimes this is useful information to have. Of course, during the period of State elections, particularly when Queensland conservative governments are in desperate trouble, we find that wilder and wilder allegations tend to be made about the Federal Government. I suppose it does take a little more effort on the part of NMLS to track down what people might be saying about the Government.

I would like to refer back for just a moment to the pretended outrage that NMLS should provide transcripts of things that are said by the Opposition. I have before me a document headed `Government Information Unit, Transcript of 2CA News, June 19 1981'. I thought: This must be a document which contains something important that had been said by some person in the Government. But, no, the document contained what had been said by Bill Hayden. It is a transcript of what the then Leader of the Opposition said.

TALK.START.PARA: —And who did it go to?

—The distribution is not marked on the bottom. But in this case the transcription services had been provided quite properly by the GIU. I would have thought that this was quite proper; perhaps Mr Baume, as he then was, does not. That is his proper judgment. But it is entirely consistent with current activities, as it should be.

SPEECH.PARA: The letter that has been the cause of this so-called furore is an absolute non-event. I was not in the chamber for Question Time. A colleague said that a letter had been incorporated in Hansard. I wondered whether something dramatic was in it. But that letter is saying that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) is going to try to find out what is said about Government policy during the course of the Queensland State election. Would not he be a very strange character if he did not do that, with all of those National Party desperates running around the back blocks of Queensland trying to drum up any reason to win a vote? Of course, we have it on very good authority what a bunch of desperates they are. We have the de facto shadow Minister for something or other, Mr Howard, saying today:
The Nationals warrant a spell on the sidelines. Their organisation deserves a clean-out. If accountability in government has any meaning they have failed some of the most basic tests . . .

That is why the Liberal Party is trying to create a diversion today about the Queensland election. As Mr Howards says in that article, everybody knows that the Liberal Party cannot govern in its own right. That is not a controversial remark; I think it is a unanimous view. Certainly, Mr Howard is correct. He is a good enough analyst to accept that it is true. Therefore, the Liberals have to govern with the National Party, this bunch of people who warrant a spell on the sidelines; this bunch of people whose organisation deserves a clean-out; this bunch of people who, in government, have failed the most basic tests of accountability.

Honourable senators opposite do not want the public to know what has occurred down south, as the Queenslanders might say, so they thought they would whip up some mock drama to try to divert attention. But it will not work. The Australian people and Queenslanders are going to be aware of the significance of coalition government in Queensland for two reasons. The first is the very effective demolition by Mr Howard of two myths-that the Liberal Party might govern in its own right and that the National Party might be a fit partner with which one could go into coalition. The second reason is that the Western Australian coalition partners are proving how impossible it is to run a decent government in coalition, bearing in mind the state of relations between the Liberal and National parties in Australia today.

The Leader of the Liberal Party has said, `I will not be in the same room as the Leader of the National Party. I will not work with him ever again. We will not work with the Nationals until they change their leader'. It sounds remarkably like Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen in the lead-up to the 1983 election. The relations that soured then have never recovered. The coalition knows that, if people ever get the chance to concentrate on whether or not a viable alternative government to a Goss Labor government exists, they will say, `No, it does not. The Liberal Party cannot govern in its own right. We do not want that bunch of desperates from the National Party back again and a coalition would be inherently unstable'. So we have a situation where there is a desperate attempt to cover up for the inadequacies of the Queensland Government.

Concern has been expressed about the use of taxpayers' money in State elections. Let me make two references. I will not speak about the National Party, whose rorting of the system was so effectively established by Senator Richardson. Rather, I will refer to the Liberal Party. Senator Baume was responsible for misleading the Senate. I am sure that this was inadvertent. He would not have done it deliberately because I know that he has respect for the chamber. We disagree on a lot of things but not on that. Senator Baume said that the person who worked for the GIU to whom I had referred by way of interjection had been to a public election meeting in Tasmania in 1982 and that it was his democratic right to do so. Of course it is his democratic right to go to any public meeting of any party, although he probably would not have had one if he had gone to a Labor Party one. I do not challenge his democratic right to do so.

The Tasmanian Liberal Party does some funny things, but I do not think it conducts its campaign committee meetings in public. The minutes of the Tasmanian Liberal Party campaign committee, which was preparing its State election campaign in 1982, reveal that Mr Montgomery was playing a key role in the Liberal Party's campaign for that election. This was revealed by Senator Button in the Senate on 11 November 1982. The information was accurate then and it has never been refuted to this day. It may be that somebody in Canberra did not know about it, but there is no doubt that it was done and that taxpayers' money was used in that State election campaign.

The Liberals in the Queensland coalition Government were a so-called check on the excesses of the National Party. While the coalition parties were in government in Queensland this abuse of the advertising process went on, just as it is going on now with the Queensland 2000 program. It had a different name in those days and now and again, very rarely, a Liberal Minister was allowed to go on the program, as long as he did not say anything with which the National Party did not agree. But the Liberal Party did not ask that its hands not be sullied. It did not say, `This might be some misuse of the taxpayers' funds and we do not want to know about it'. It said, `Please let us into the white cars at any price'. That is what this debate is about.

The Queensland Liberal Party knows that if ever a party had a classic situation where it ought to do very well in an election, it is the Queensland Liberal Party because although the Queensland Government has been absolutely discredited, it has been there for 32 years. When people are not used to change, the easiest campaign position in the world is to go back just six years-not 32 years-to how it used to be in coalition. As a person who has been a bit of an analyst of election campaigns a bit too long, I say that would be a very easy campaign to run and that one would have to be a mug to blow it-and the mugs have blown it! Despite the very easy campaign that they ought to be able to run, they know that the opinion polls are saying that three years ago they had a golden opportunity and they blew it. They are now doing it again, so they have rung up down here asking for something that might divert attention from the fact that the only real alternative Premiers are Russell Cooper and Wayne Goss.

We have this desperate attempt by Mr Howard to talk about Mr Angus Innes as the third man of Queensland politics-sort of the Harry Lime of Queensland. That really is not a goer. There might be some very interesting analogies in that reference in terms of the way Queensland politics is being conducted, but it does not take us very far as a proposal that he can be seriously considered as the Premier. Not even the Liberal Party considered that. It wanted to throw him out and get a new leader before the election, but she would not come into the Parliament because she knew that the Liberals could not get elected.

The coalition knows it cannot win in Queensland; it knows that the National Party is discredited; and it knows that the Liberal Party cannot win. The Liberal Party does not want the public to become aware of the fact that it can govern only with the discredited Nationals. It wants to divert attention from Mr Howard's very effective demolition job of the National Party. It wants to divert attention from the absolute debacle in the coalition in Western Australia and pretend that this confected outrage about a letter from someone who does not even work for the National Media Liaison Service, who is not offering the services of the National Media Liaison Service to the Labor Party, if stretched far enough might justify a rehash of all the old speeches about the NMLS. The Liberal Party thinks that, if it pretends that the GIU did not provide information to all the people who were to participate in this debate on behalf of the Liberal Party, it might just divert the attention of one or two voters. All I can say is that the Australian Democrats and the Press Gallery both got it right: they did not bother to turn up. The proposal does not warrant the time of the Senate. It is a pity that we are not debating the Appropriation Bills; the sooner we get back to them the better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Any observer of politics knows that where mock rage and anger are spilled out across the chamber, as they were by the two Government members who have just spoken, there is a gross failure on the part of those speakers to address the real issues. It is about time that we reminded ourselves what they are. This matter of public importance, so ably moved today by my colleague, Senator Short, states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Hawke Government's misuse of the taxpayer-funded National Media Liaison Service for blatant party political purposes in ALP state election campaigns.

That is the general proposition, but what are the specifics about which we are talking? I will make the case that there is no point easier to prove than that the Labor Party at this very moment is misusing the National Media Liaison Service (NMLS) in the Queensland context by virtue of the evidence that has been produced by a letter addressed from the office of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, to his colleague, the Leader of the Australian Labor Party in Queensland, Mr Goss.

Why is it so easy to prove? First, Senator Richardson, who led for the Government on this debate, made the point at the outset that this is in response to activities of the present National Party Government in Queensland. Senator Richardson referred to a television program that has been running not for the last few months, not for the last few years, but for many years to promote aspects of Queensland Government activity. He then used this as a justification for why the Labor Party has used the NMLS to become involved in the election campaign in Queensland. No case could be easier to prove than that. Senator Richardson spoke those words. He has demonstrated that the only reason for the NMLS to be involved is that it needs to counter the activities of the Queensland National Party Government. He has admitted that this electoral activity is being undertaken. That being so, what are the tests of the Hawke Government's approach in terms of whether we can rely on what it has set down as guidelines for managing the NMLS? I turn to the statement by Senator Robert Ray who, on 23 October 1987 in a Senate Estimates committee, spelt out quite clearly the role and function of the NMLS. Point (d) states:
Representatives will not work with local or State Party branches and will not be involved in Party programs nor electoral campaigning.

That proves the point: it is the intention of the Government, by its own rules, that the NMLS will not be involved in electoral campaigning. As I have already pointed out, Senator Richardson has condoned the activities of the NMLS by drawing attention to the fact that it is there for one purpose only; that is, to combat the activities of the National Party Government in Queensland. The case has been proven by Senator Richardson himself. There is every reason, therefore, for the Government to desist immediately from this activity and the NMLS should withdraw from its activities in Queensland.

All of these things are well known. During the 1987 Federal election campaign, the newly appointed head of the NMLS, Colin Parks, became involved in political activities. We know of the way in which transcripts not only were prepared and disseminated to Government Ministers for their information, but also were spread around like confetti to the Press Gallery so that the arguments could be picked up by the Press Gallery and used against the Opposition parties at that time. Senator McMullan tried, in a plausible way, to make out that somehow, as long as the NMLS monitors the operations of the Opposition and then spreads the transcripts around to Ministers, that is okay. I have to say that we in the Liberal and National parties would agree with that. However, that is not where the matter stops. As we all know, the operations of the NMLS go to spreading around information of this kind and Mr Parks and his offsiders actively promote points to the press in such a way as to ensure that the Government's point of view is put across and that the Opposition is seen in the worst possible light.

That is what is wrong with the argument that Senator McMullan and Senator Richardson have put forward. That is why they have failed to convince us on this side of the Parliament that there is any validity in what has happened. It is just fortuitous that, as luck would have it, the letter referred to in this debate, which was addressed to Mr Goss, that so-called self-proclaimed paragon of virtue in Queensland-the Leader of the Labor Party-stated that, in fact, he was entitled to get all the support he might claim from the Federal National Media Liaison Service which is paid for by the taxpayer and operated by the Hawke Labor Government. That is the case in a nutshell. We do not have to go too far back to demonstrate that that is the core of today's debate.

We on this side of the House know, from our investigation in the Estimates committees, that in the period since the Government came to power in 1983 the cost of running the NMLS is more than $12m. Furthermore, we are aware of the considerable activities of press secretaries who operate from ministerial offices. There is also, literally, a football team-if not more-of consultants who have similar capacities over and above those of the press secretaries paid for from the ministerial vote. A consultant to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), Mr N. G. Freudenberg, who is well-known to us all, undertakes the political role for the Prime Minister in many ways. In Mr Lionel Bowen's office, a Mr Ainsworth undertakes media relations activities on behalf of Mr Bowen. Mr Geoff Walsh, who is also in Mr Bowen's office, undertakes similar activities. In Senator Button's office a Mr Bremner is there to monitor, evaluate and advise at a high level on press releases and matters of that kind. A Dr Gold is also in that office. In the office of Senator Gareth Evans, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, there is a Mr B. A. Grant. The list goes on.

The point I would make is that, irrespective of what the Government claims is the cost of the National Media Liaison Service, this is just the tip of the iceberg because below that is the cost to the taxpayer of several million dollars paid to consultants who act in much the same capacity as-and no doubt in conjunction with-the taxpayer-funded National Media Liaison Service.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a way of getting around the rules.

—As my colleague points out, it is a way of getting round the rules. It is well-known in the Public Service that consultants are often used in this capacity. This is supplementary information which has not been revealed. We have no way of challenging these payments because they are hidden in the bowels of the Budget. Consequently, they are appointments which we cannot raise during debate in the Parliament. We can mention them only in the context of this kind of activity. We would like the Government to tell us what the real cost is of its thought police operations in this country. Quite obviously they are having a significant impact on the taxpayer's dollar and obviously they are being used for straight-out political activities. That case has been overwhelmingly proven today by speakers from the Liberal and National parties and admitted, by way of implication, by the Minister in charge of the National Media Liaison Service.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to some of the furphies that are around. Senator McMullan and Senator Richardson have said that the head of the NMLS, Mr Parks, takes no part in the political activities of the Australian Labor Party. That would have to be one of the greatest nonsenses of all time. We know, as it has been admitted, that in the 1987 election campaign Mr Parks was ensconced in John Curtin House, the Australian Labor Party's building in Canberra, during every meeting and operation of the Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —At taxpayers' expense.

—As Senator Reid points out, it was all at taxpayers' expense. Are we to believe that he was there to act as a tea lady or to serve biscuits to the people who were active in the campaign and that he was never asked for his advice or asked to comment on the media operations of the Labor Party during that campaign? Of course not. We know that he was the funnel for media transcripts to be transmitted from his network of operatives in the various States right into the heart of the Australian Labor Party's 1987 election campaign. As we know, that election turned out to be a victory for the Labor Party, but it was a very hollow victory because the Liberal and National parties together polled more votes than the Labor Party did, although they failed to win the election. It is a fact of life that we in the Liberal and National parties have to live with, that we outpolled Labor but lost the election.

SPEECH.PARA: That indicates, I think, the degree of ability and the power that emanates from the activities of the National Media Liaison Service. We all remember that during that election campaign the thought police were able to so monitor the operations of the Liberal and National parties as to be able, effectively, to use the media in individual electorates where it mattered. That is what demonstrates, again, the effectiveness of that little operation. For the Government to come in here and say that Mr Parks acted purely as a government agent, paid for as a public servant, and had no role in working within the Labor Party campaign leaves me breathless. I am sure that when the Australian people are aware of all these facts they will agree.

The effects of all this are already showing on the political landscape of this country. This body has gone beyond its charter. It has gone beyond what was set down by Senator Ray in his 1987 statement. It has exceeded its activities and authority by undertaking a new role in the Queensland State election. Obviously it will run blocking tactics in Queensland during the current campaign, doing so in direct response-as was admitted by Senator Richardson today-to what the Queensland National Party has done over a long period. That is the justification for this action. It is admitted and it is wrong. The Government is condemned for undertaking such activity. There should be an immediate instruction from Senator Richardson that the operatives of the NMLS in Queensland desist from any further activities in the Queensland election campaign.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Sir Charles Court-North West Shelf Project

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following arrangements with the Opposition Whip, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

There are few spectacles as tragic as that of yesterday's politicians pretending they are still important and attempting to rewrite history in order to cover up their mistakes. For most of this year we have seen that spectacle in operation with the former Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, swanning around the world trying to persuade the Commonwealth that he should be its Secretary-General. As a result of the report, which was tabled this morning, of the Committee of Privileges, which is chaired by Senator Giles, we have the spectacle of Sir Charles Court trying to cover up his mistakes. Normally I would not speak on the adjournment but the letter tendered by Sir Charles to the Committee is a mixture of internal inconsistency, of errors of omission, and of false assertions. The letter is basically stereotype Court-skite. A paragraph on page 4 states:
There was no direction or pressure applied to the State Electricity Commission to sign this agree- ment . . .

He cannot have it both ways. If, on the interpretation of this document as being standardised Court-skite, Sir Charles Court is claiming to be responsible for everything that happened with the North West Shelf, he cannot simultaneously say that the decision to sign the take or pay contract was an autonomous decision of the State Electricity Commission. So much for the internal inconsistency. The most serious error of omission is that he neglects to mention that some 16 per cent of the total take or pay contract was gratuitously added on to the contract by him. That has been a major source of the embarrassment. I will deal with a few other assertions and false assertions. The letter states on page 4:
Without this take or pay contract for domestic gas no export LNG phase . . . would have been possible.

That is an assertion. He claims that it was false for me to say that the Western Australian Government requested financial relief from the Commonwealth because of the disastrous consequences of the take or pay contract. That is a false assertion. That is precisely why the Western Australian Government approached the Commonwealth for assistance to get out of the financial jam into which the take or pay contract had placed the State Electricity Commission (SEC), and therefore the Government. Sir Charles asserts:

Any deal worked out in 1984-85 between the Federal and W.A. . . . Governments in respect of the project was entirely between the two Labor Governments of the time and not because of the agreement negotiated by my Government and SEC.

That statement is plainly false. In fact, a report published by the Western Australian Government in 1985 showed that the accumulated losses on the then projections of actual gas sales would have totalled some $7 billion. He goes on to say:
No such negotiations with the Commonwealth Government would have been necessary nor would have taken place had I continued in office and not retired from Parliament . . .
The agreement my Government and the SEC negotiated had ample provision for renegotiation with the Joint Venturers if circumstances changed.

That statement is false. Sir Charles's defence of his role in this sorry saga has also varied over time. Some three years ago he asserted in a letter to the West Australian that in fact it was good business for the State to be paying for the gas in the early 1980s which may be used in the year 2000. I suggested at the time, as I have suggested since, that, if Sir Charles really believes this, he should put together a private consortium to buy the gas which is paid for and leave it in the ground, because I am quite sure that the State Government and the SEC would be happy to sell it. He has never attempted to act on that suggestion. But his tune has now changed. In the letter which is republished in the Committee's report he said:
. . . I understand SEC is already taking its full contract figure.

I do not know whether that is true. If it is true, one of the reasons is that to the SEC, having been required by the contract to buy the gas whether it was needed or not, any price in excess of the cost of pumping the gas down from the North West Shelf was a price that would have been acceptable. In the second paragraph on page 6 of the report reproducing Sir Charles's letter, he says:
It is also realistic to assume that the gas will yield higher prices to SEC in years of sale . . .

It may be realistic to assume that. However, that statement indicates that Sir Charles is unaware of the principle of the time value of money or discounting; he is either unaware of it or he chooses to ignore it. He goes on to say:
Had I not encouraged the negotiation of the take or pay agreement . . .

The Senate should bear in mind that he claimed earlier in his letter that it was a spontaneous decision by the SEC. The tune has changed a bit there. He says that if he had not done so he would have been accused of being a person with no vision. Again, that is quite wrong. In an article published in the Independent monthly newspaper I specifically referred to Sir Charles as a man of vision. The theme of the article was the high cost of visionaries. He certainly had many visions-hallucinations might be a more accurate description of them. In that article I referred to his visions concerning a Peruvian con man called Dr Shrian Oskar, who was funded by the taxpayers to establish an oil seed mill in Bunbury, the Ord River scheme, the Manjimup cannery-which had more rescues than Rothwells-and so on, and so forth. I put these matters on the record because otherwise the matter would have little interest next week.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not respond to the comments made by Senator Walsh because I have not had a proper opportunity to read the submission by Sir Charles Court to the Committee of Privileges. However, when we talk about the activities and the careers of parliamentary leaders having left parliament, one cannot help but reflect upon the ascension of Mr Hayden to the position of Governor-General. One cannot help noting Mr Whitlam's activities since leaving the Parliament. One cannot help but note Mr Burke's ascension since leaving parliament-Senator Walsh might call it `swanning around'.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the Senate of some comments made by the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) at the opening in Perth of the North West Shelf, stage 2, on 19 September 1989. The Prime Minister said:

Forty years ago, on the other side of this vast continent, the Australian people began construction of one of the largest and most complex engineering projects in the world: the Snowy Mountains Scheme.

Today, we celebrate a milestone in another massive feat of Australian engineering: the North West Shelf project. It's called upon the same capacity for vision and the same reserves of human skill and dedication that characterised the Snowy Mountains Scheme, and it's created an industry that will foster Australian jobs and Australian exports into the twenty-first century.

Australians may perhaps be blase about the magnitude of resource projects throughout our continent: the huge coal fields in the eastern States, the vast iron-ore mines in this State, the oil fields of Bass Strait, our bauxite, gold and copper mines.
He is talking about the North West Shelf gas project for which Sir Charles Court is given credit by most, but criticism by Senator Walsh. The Prime Minister continues:
But this one dwarfs them all. The North West Shelf project is, simply, the largest single resource project in our history and perhaps the largest anywhere in the world.

Back in the 1960s, not even the most optimistic of people who saw a small company called Woodside Petroleum acquire a number of exploration permits in the remote north-west of Western Australia could have imagined the scale of the discoveries that were to be made, or the magnitude of the development those discoveries sparked:
- 375 billion cubic metres of natural gas;
- $12 billion in investment expenditure;
- 8,000 jobs onsite and offsite;
- exports worth up to $2 billion a year from 1994.

What that barrage of figures tells us, very simply, is this: for a nation dependent as Australia is on successful competition on the world's marketplaces, the North West Shelf represents a massive contribution to our economic well-being and to the prosperity of future generations of Australia.

That is why, as Prime Minister, it is my very great pleasure to congratulate the joint venturers on their tremendous achievement in bringing this project to fruition; to welcome the support of the eight Japanese electricity and gas utilities who will purchase LNG from the North West Shelf; to pay tribute to the work of the National Liaison Group, which has played a vital constructive role throughout the duration of this project; and to thank the skill, energy and commitment of the thousands of workers and staff who have given their best efforts to this project. It is of course a matter of regret to me that-due to a variety of circumstances-we are not gathered at Karratha today to see this great project. I certainly look forward to inspecting it one day.
Ladies and Gentlemen,
I've been making the point recently, in discussing Australian's economic position, that we are undergoing an investment boom.

Those who are worried about our current account deficit should come to the North West Shelf and see the way in which this project-dependent as it has been in part on foreign investment-will translate into future export growth.

Across the whole spectrum of industry-not just in resource projects but throughout the manufacturing sector-investment which today is contributing to our current account deficit is laying the foundations for substantial export growth in the future.
At the same time it's impressive that such a large proportion of the work on North West Shelf has in fact been performed by Australian industry.
Of the more than $6 billion already spent, about three quarters has been spent in Australia.

In other words, Australian industry can compete with the best of them when it comes to major resource projects like this; at the same time we have acquired new skills and capacities which will help make us even better partners in major resource and engineering projects in the future.
He then said:
I want to express a special welcome to our Japanese guests today.
Exports from the North West Shelf mark the beginning of a new phase in the already very healthy relationship between Australia and Japan.
The future is very bright for both of us.

In the mid 1990s, this project will be providing some 15 per cent of Japan's LNG imports. And Australia can play an even greater role in supplying energy resources to Japan. Over the next decade, energy exports to Japan could treble in real terms to $3 billion a year.
Ladies and Gentlemen,

The North West Shelf has been completed on budget, and two months ahead of schedule. That's a great achievement in itself-proof, if more was needed, of the hard work, cooperative spirit and sheer dedication brought to this project by thousands of people.
I offer my congratulations to you all and my confident best wishes for the future of this great project.

Those are the comments of the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, in response to this project which, in my view, certainly would not have commenced or been completed without the personal commitment and dedication of Sir Charles Court-as has been acknowledged by people such as Brian Burke. That contribution, that dedication, that foresight and that wisdom contrast in a realistic way with the present Labor Government in Western Australia which, if my memory serves me correctly, has received more than a sharp tongue-lashing from Senator Walsh himself, not the least being on the evening of the last State election. That contrasts with the hundreds of millions of dollars of investment made by that Government on behalf of the Australian taxpayers in the aborted petrochemical industry which, of course, will now be lost for all time at great cost to all Australian taxpayers. Senator Walsh was unreasonable and, in my view, unfair and inaccurate in the comments he made in respect of Sir Charles Court who, on only a very superficial reading of what he has said, seems to have set out the situation and the facts in a clear, concise and proper way.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 3.44 p.m. until Monday, 30 October 1989, at 2 p.m.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Transport and Communications: Recycled Paper

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 8 August 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the total amount of paper used annually by the Minister's department or departments and what is the value of this paper.
(2) What steps has the Minister taken to institute the use of re-cycled paper by the department or departments in his/her portfolio.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: I cannot justify expending the enormous resources needed systematically to review the excellent record of the three Hawke governments as sought by the honourable Senator. However, set out below is a two-part answer. Part A contains a sample of decisions by the third Hawke Government.
