PART A
Some examples from the tourism area are as follows:
Amendment of Australian Tourist Commission Act.

Following the report of the Australian Government Inquiry into Tourism in 1986, the Australian Tourist Commission Act was amended in December 1987 to include, inter alia, provisions to ensure that Australia is protected from the adverse environmental and social impacts of international tourism (para 6 (c)) and to closely monitor and report on the effects of international tourism on Australia's natural environment and society (para 7 (e)).
Tourism in the Antarctic.

In March 1988, I asked the House of Representatives Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts to inquire into and report on tourism in the Antarctic, including reference to the impact on the environment. The Committee reported in May 1989.
Reference to Industries Assistance Commission.

In July 1988 the Treasurer referred the travel and tourism industry to the Industries Assistance Commission for inquiry and report. The Commission was required to examine the factors affecting the development of the industry, including major impediments to competitiveness and efficiency. Environmental issues were addressed during the inquiry. The Commission released its draft report in June 1989.
Discussion Paper on `Directions for Tourism'.

The Government circulated in September 1988 a Discussion Paper titled `Directions for Tourism', which proposed broad objectives as the basis for the future development of the Government's tourism policy. This paper included objectives and discussion of environmental issues related to tourism.
Environmental Guidelines for Tourism Developments.

In October 1988, at the meeting of the Tourist Ministers' Council, I undertook to have the Commonwealth prepare a set of draft environmental guidelines for tourism developments. These will be considered by Ministers at the November 1989 of Tourist Ministers' Council.
Some examples from the Antarctic Division are as follows:
Antarctic research.
A substantial program of Antarctic research investigating issues relevant to the environment with 135 projects will be conducted in 1989-90.
Heard and McDonald Islands.
Introduction of the Heard and McDonald Islands Environment Protection and Management Ordinance in January 1988.
Aurora Australis.

The Commonwealth has signed a charter for the new Antarctic research/resupply vessel, Aurora Australis, with special capabilities for research on environmental matters relating to the southern ocean ecosystem, oceanography and weather and climate. Aurora Australis has been designed so that it will have no fuel between its inner and outer holds to limit environmental damage in the case of grounding-a feature not found on any other Antarctic vessel. The Aurora Australis, the first Australian built, flagged and crewed ice strengthened research and supply ship, is scheduled to enter service in the 1989-90 Antarctic season.
Upgrading of scientific facilities.

Decisions have been taken to proceed with scientific laboratories at Australia's Antarctic Stations which will significantly enhance Australia's ability to conduct environmental research in Antarctica.
Prevention of Mining or Oil Drilling.

The Government decided not to sign the Convention on the Regulation of Antarctic Mineral Resource Activities but to seek the establishment of an Antarctic Wilderness Park and arrangements which will prevent mining or oil drilling in Antarctica and a comprehensive environmental protection convention for Antarctica.
Ethnics Inquiry.

A Working Group of the Antarctic Science Advisory Committee examined procedures to ensure that the conduct of Antarctic research projects involving animals (including the specific techniques and conditions for experiments) is justified, taking into account animal welfare and conservation implications.
Radiation Code of Conduct.

A set of guidelines for the purchase, safe storage, transport, use and disposal of radioisotopes was developed. The guidelines are designed to ensure the safety of scientists and support staff participating in the Australian Antarctic program, and the protection of the Antarctic environment from contamination. The guidelines are being used as the basis of a code which is expected to be finalised in October 1989.
Establishment of Ethics Committee.

The Antarctic Animal Care and Ionising Radiation Usage Ethics Committee was established to develop and maintain a code of practice, and to examine research proposals involving the use of animals and ionising radiation use.
No more use of Hydroponics.

A decision has been taken to cease hydroponic cultivation at Australia's Antarctic stations to minimise the possibility of the accidental introduction of external flora and fauna to the Antarctic environment.
Guidelines for Environment Assessment.
The Antarctic Division has introduced decision/action guidelines for the assessment of the environmental implications of activities to be conducted in Antarctica.
Convention on the Conservation of Antarctic Seals.
The Convention on the Conservation of Antarctic Seals was ratified.
Waste disposal.

Australia initiated a comprehensive program to clean up Australian Antarctic stations, introduced strict waste disposal guidelines for stations and environmental training for all expedition participants, and began the development of management plans for Antarctic stations. The Antarctic Division is now giving priority to a program to return rubbish and clean up the areas around Australia's Antarctic stations.

PART B
HAWKE GOVERNMENT'S ENVIRONMENTAL ACHIEVEMENTS 1983-1989
World Heritage

The World Heritage Convention protects the world's cultural and natural heritage. It is the most successful and respected international agreement in the field of heritage conservation. Australia is a world leader in implementing the Convention, being the only country which has enacted legislation to carry out its responsibilities under the Convention.

The Government introduced the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act in 1983 to fulfil its obligation under the Convention to protect and conserve areas of outstanding universal value within Australia. The Act was used to put in place regulations which prevented the construction of the Gordon-Below-Franklin Dam and the logging of the North Queensland rainforests.

Australia has eight properties on the World Heritage List: Kakadu National Park; The Great Barrier Reef; The Willandra Lakes Region of Western NSW; The Lord Howe Island Group off the coast of NSW; The Western Tasmania Wilderness National Parks; The Australian East Coast Temperate and Sub-Tropical Rainforest Parks (the NSW Rainforests); Uluru National Park; The Wet Tropics of Queensland.
South-West Tasmania

Almost 1.4 million hectares, or about 20% of Tasmania, will be protected by World Heritage Listing following the World Heritage nomination in December 1988. The area includes spectacular examples of the tallest forests in the Southern Hemisphere-the increasingly rare, pristine tall eucalypt forests. The new areas are expected to be placed on the World Heritage List in December, 1989 and are in addition to the existing Western Tasmania Wilderness National Parks which were declared a World Heritage area in 1982. South-West Tasmania is one of the world's greatest temperate wilderness areas. The World Heritage nomination, which was favourably reviewed by the World Heritage Bureau in Paris in June, 1989, protects valuable areas of rainforest, King Billy pines estimated to be several thousand years old, alpine vegetation, archaeological sites, rare and threatened species and the tall forests.

As part of the World Heritage agreement, in November 1988 the Federal and Tasmanian Governments signed a $30 million five year timber industry assistance package. The package encourages responsible and sustainable forestry while protecting important environmental values. A major commitment to plantations in the package will offset resource losses, and help the industry become less reliant on native forests in the future.
NSW Rainforests and Uluru National Park

The Australian East Coast Temperate and Sub-Tropical Rainforest Parks were placed on the World Heritage List in 1986. Uluru National Park became Australia's seventh World Heritage property in 1987. In 1985, the Federal Government granted inalienable freehold title of the Park to the traditional Aboriginal owners. The area is leased back to the Government for use as a national park for the benefit of all Australians and the international community.
Wet Tropical Rainforests

The World Heritage Committee formally inscribed the Wet Tropics of Queensland on the World Heritage List in December, 1988. Earlier in the year, regulations made under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act brought an end to rainforest logging in the nominated area of about 8,900 sq. km. A $75 million package of job creation, management, plantation and infrastructure initiatives was introduced to compensate those affected by listing.
Ozone Layer Protection

In March, 1989, the Commonwealth passed tough legislation which places Australia at the forefront of international action to phase out the use of ozone destroying chlorofluorocarbons (CFC's) and halons. Australia and Sweden are the two countries which have acted fastest on CFC and halon elimination.

Under the Commonwealth legislation, the import and manufacture of aerosol sprays with CFC's will be banned from the end of 1989. There will also be a range of other controls on the end uses of CFC's and halons in air-conditioning, refrigeration, fire extinguishers, foams, insulation, and electronic and fabric cleaning.

A National Ozone Strategy developed by the Commonwealth and State Governments-in consultation with industry and public interest groups-was adopted in July, 1989. The National Strategy will cut CFC and halon use in Australia by an estimated 95% by the year 1995. This is significantly faster than required under the Montreal Protocol which Australia signed on June 8, 1988. The strategy is also far tougher than new controls expected to come from the revision of the Montreal Protocol which will be finalised in 1990. Halons and CFC's are also greenhouse gases and the cuts in their use to 5% of 1986 levels by 1995 will reduce Australia's greenhouse gas emissions by approximately 17%.
Greenhouse
Australia has committed itself to a comprehensive program of research, public education and immediate action on the Greenhouse Effect.

In April, 1989, the Government announced an additional $7.8 million for Greenhouse research till June 30, 1990. The Prime Minister has said that this is only the first stage of an ongoing commitment which will ensure Australia is at the forefront of international Greenhouse research. Australia is well placed to do critical research in the Southern Hemisphere which will ensure that global models now being developed are complete and accurate.

Australia has also pledged another $6.25 million over five years to a climate modelling program which will record and help predict changes in sea levels, air temperature and rainfall patterns in the South Pacific as a result of the Greenhouse Effect. It is anticipated that this program will be maintained for at least 20 years.

A National Greenhouse Advisory Committee was set up in 1989. It will provide expert policy advice and promote public understanding of the issues. $350,000 has been allocated for the first two years of a public education program.

A preliminary report on the technical aspects of reducing Australia's Greenhouse gas emissions is being prepared. The Prime Minister's `Our Country, Our Future' Environment Statement said that Australia will play its part in reducing global greenhouse gas emissions, both domestically and internationally.

On 3 October 1989 the Australian and New Zealand Environment Council resolved to investigate ways to reduce greenhouse gases by up to 40%. In addition, the Council adopted the Commonwealth's proposal to reduce energy use by examining (a) minimum standards of energy efficiency in new government buildings and for domestic appliances; (b) more efficient domestic water heating services and household lighting (using compact fluorescent globes); and (c) fuel consumption standards for cars and light duty vehicles.
Antarctica

The Government decided that Australia should not sign the Antarctic Minerals Convention and initiated discussions with Antarctic Treaty countries with the aim of negotiating a comprehensive Antarctic environmental protection convention and having Antarctica declared a wilderness park free from all mining activity.

Australia successfully pushed for and continues to seek improvements in environmental protection amongst Antarctic Treaty nations. This includes a new Antarctic protected area category, environmental impact assessment, Southern Ocean ecosystem conservation and stronger waste disposal requirements.
The Convention on the Conservation of Antarctic Seals was ratified.

Australia initiated a comprehensive program to clean up Australian Antarctic stations, introduced strict waste disposal guidelines for stations and environmental training for all expedition participants, and began management plans for Antarctic stations.

The Antarctic has emerged as a critical laboratory for study of the Greenhouse effect and the depletion of the ozone layer. Research on the history of climate change and future trends makes up more than one-quarter of the Antarctic science program.

Since 1986 the Antarctic Science Advisory Committee (ASAC) and the ASAC Grants Scheme, has allocated $1.4 million for Antarctic scientific research projects. This is in addition to scientific research undertaken by the Australian Antarctic Division which in 1988-89 spent over $10 million on its land based and marine science programs.
An animal care and ethics committee was established to oversee Antarctic scientific work involving animals.

The Auora Australis, the first Australian built, flagged and crewed ice strengthened research and supply ship, was launched on 18 September 1989, and will enter service in the 1989-90 Antarctic season.

A major construction program has rebuilt the Casey Base, and significant parts of the Davis and Mawson bases. ANARESAT, a satellite system has brought rapid and reliable voice and data communications between Australia and its Antarctic stations.
A recruitment drive to attract women to work in Antarctic was initiated. In 1988-89, Australia became the first country to appoint women station leaders to Antarctic.

An Endangered Species Advisory Committee (ESAC) and an Endangered Species Unit within the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service (ANPWS) were established in 1988. ESAC represents conservation groups, the rural community and Commonwealth and State nature agencies. It is formulating a national strategy to conserve endangered species and their habitats.
Great Barrier Reef Marine Park

One of the first environmental actions by the Hawke Government after assuming office in 1983 was extending the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park from 14% to 98% of the Great Barrier Reef Region. By August, 1988, zoning plans for all the 344,000 square kilometre marine park area were in place, making it the world's largest and most significant marine conservation project. The marine park is co-operatively and jointly managed by the Commonwealth and Queensland Governments.

The Government has supported the world's most extensive research program on the Crown of Thorns starfish. The multi-disciplinary research is trying to determine the causes, measure the effects and identify suitable control mechanisms. Three million dollars will be spent on this research over the next 3 years. Population outbreaks on coral reefs are now a problem throughout the Indo-Pacific region.
Kakadu

Stage 2 of Kakadu National Park was declared in 1983 and placed on the World Heritage List in 1987. In 1986, the Government purchased the Gimbat and Goodparla pastoral leases, which comprise much of the headwaters of the South Alligator River. About 65% of Gimbat and Goodparla became Stage 3 of the Park in June, 1987.

The remainder of the Gimbat and Goodparla leases became a Conservation Zone under the provisions of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation (NPWC) Act. On October 5, 1989, the Government decided to prevent mining in 98% of the Conservation Zone by incorporating this area into Stage 3 of the Park. The remaining 37 square km strip along a small section of the South Alligator River will be known as an exploration zone. The Resource Assessment Commission has been asked to examine the economic and environmental considerations of any mining development in this exploration zone. The RAC inquiry will also investigate the Jawoyn's aboriginal sacred site claim under the Commonwealth Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act.
In 1987, the Government amended the NPWC Act to prohibit mining in the Park.

The wetlands of Stage One of the Park were included on the list of areas recognised under the Convention on Wetlands of International Importance Especially as Waterfowl Habitat. The wetlands of Stage Two are expected to be added soon.

Significant work has been done by the ANPWS to eliminate mimosa, an introduced plant, and buffalo from the Park. Mimosa is seriously degrading Top End flood plain ecosystems. The elimination of buffalo from the Park over the last few years has dramatically improved the recovery of vegetation on the floodplain and in Stage 3. Fears have been raised that the migration of the cane toad will see it eventually invade Kakadu with devastating effects on wildlife. The Government is investigating possible biological controls agents.

Work is progressing on the respective inventories for North Queensland and South Australia. Funding for the program will be accelerated to ensure its rapid completion nationally.
Native Forests
$2.9 million has been allocated over the next three years for the setting up of a National Forests Inventory. The inventory will include a survey of old growth forests in Australia.
Resource Assessment Commission

Legislation establishing the Commission was passed in June, 1989. The Commission is an independent body which will investigate major, complex resource, land use and environment issues referred to it by Government. RAC's first inquiries will be into forest and timber resources, the Kakadu exploration Zone and management of Australia's coastline. Justice Stewart has been appointed chairperson.
Wesley Vale

The North Broken Hill/Noranda Forests Inc joint ventures dropped their plans for a $1 billion pulp mill at Wesley Vale in north-west Tasmania after the Federal Government insisted on tougher environment conditions than the companies had negotiated with the Tasmanian Government. The Government was particularly concerned about the impact of 13 tonnes of organochlorines which would have been dumped in Bass Strait every day. By the end of 1989, the Government will have established a set of guidelines for pulp mill projects which will ensure Australia has the toughest and best standards of any country in the world.
National Industrial Chemicals Notification Scheme

The Government introduced legislation in the 1989 Budget session of Parliament which will set up a notification and assessment scheme for hazardous industrial chemicals. Under the scheme, all new and some existing industrial chemicals will be evaluated to assess their potential hazards to people and the environment.
Waste Management

The Government has introduced legislation to control hazardous waste exports and imports. Australia was active in the successful drafting of the UNEP Convention on Hazardous Wastes. Australia was also a party to the London Dumping Convention's decision to phase out incineration of noxious liquid wastes at sea by the end of 1994.
Australia has previously had to rely on the export of intractable wastes for disposal overseas, principally in the U.K. where those wastes have been destroyed by high temperature incineration.

The Commonwealth is co-operating with the NSW and Victorian Governments in developing a national high temperature incinerator for the disposal of certain intractable wastes such as PCB's and some organochlorines. The proposal is being developed by an independent task force set up by the governments. The task force is currently consulting extensively on issues of design and siting. As a result of agreement by the NSW Government, the facility will be located somewhere in that State.

The Commonwealth played a leading role in the development by the Australian Environment Ministers Council (comprising Commonwealth and State Environment Ministers) of National Guidelines for the Management of Hazardous Wastes agreed to in 1986. The guidelines describe a comprehensive set of measures for the satisfactory management of these materials. The States are now implementing these standards.
Voluntary Conservation Organisations

When the Government came to power in March, 1983, grants to voluntary conservation organisations had been about $350,000 for some years. Over the following two years, this was increased to $635,000 then $850,000. In 1988-89, 44 voluntary conservation organisations will receive $1.116 million in Federal grants. In addition to the above grants, the Government initiated a system of meetings with peak conservation organisations which are held two or three times every year. The meetings allow the groups to raise major environmental issues directly with the Minister.
Murray-Darling Basin

In November, 1985, the Federal, Victorian, New South Wales and South Australian Governments established the Murray-Darling Basin Ministerial Council. The Council provides a strategic focus for planning and managing the Basin's natural resources to achieve sustainable use.

One of the first projects initiated by the Council was a major Environmental Resources Study. Published in 1987, the study detailed the extent and severity of degradation of the Basin's environmental resources. This degradation is estimated to cause losses to agriculture of $260 million per year. River salinity costs are estimated at a further $35 million per year.
In addition to the Environmental Resources Study, the Council has also:
initiated studies involving on-farm water use and irrigation;
released a Salinity and Drainage Strategy; and
developed a draft Natural Resources Management Strategy with an indicative three year budget of $45.2 million.
One Billion Trees

The One Billion Trees program was announced by the Prime Minister in the `Our Country, Our Future' Environment Statement on July 20, 1989. With direct Commonwealth funding of $4.7 million a year supplemented by State, industry and community contributions, the program will ensure that at least one billion additional trees will be growing by the end of the century. It is estimated that over 200 million trees have been established since the National Tree Program was established in 1982.

The Save the Bush program, also announced by the Prime Minister on July 20, 1989, provides $1 million in 1989-90 and increasing funds in later years for conserving the last vestiges of our once extensive forests, woodlands and grasslands (over two-thirds of Australia's original tree cover has been removed since European settlement). These small remnants of our national heritage often precariously surviving on farms and along roadsides, provide habitat and migration corridors for our unique wildlife. They are an essential but all too often neglected adjunct to Australia's national parks system.
National Rainforest Conservation Program

In June, 1986, the Government provided $22.25 million for the establishment of a national program on rainforest conservation with the States. Queensland is the only Australian state with rainforest which has not joined the Commonwealth initiated program.
Drift Net Fishing

Australia was instrumental in framing the Tarawa Declaration at the 20th South Pacific Forum meeting in July, 1989. The declaration says that drift netting violates international law and calls on Japan and Taiwan to immediately abandon their operations in the South Pacific. It also called on the rest of the world to support a convention banning the use of drift nets in the Pacific. It is claimed drift net fishing could lead to the collapse of the South Pacific tuna fishery in the next few years.
I thank the Honourable Senator for this opportunity to list some of the achievements of this Government over the last two years or so.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Administrative Services: Transport Charges

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 16 August 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the press report of 19 July 1989 correct in that the New South Wales Government awarded the contract to provide transport to that State's judges and other judicial office holders to the Transport and Storage Group of the Commonwealth Department of Administrative Services.
(2) Is it also correct that: (a) the per kilometre charge is $0.60; and (b) this is lower than that charged by taxis in Sydney.
(3) What costs does this per kilometre charge cover and can he confirm that this charge is economically based.
(4) What are the approximate per kilometre costs based on the hourly rate charged for the transportation of Federal Members and Senators:
(5) What are the reasons for: (a) using different methods of charging; and (b) the difference, if any, between the charges to the NSW Government and to Commonwealth Parliamentarians.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) (a) The 1988/89 rate was $0.60 per kilometre. An application to increase the rate to $0.69 per kilometre for 1989/90 has been lodged with the State Contracts Board. These rates are set on a ``depot to depot'' basis which includes the distance from the car depot to the passenger pickup point, the actual journey with the passenger and, after the passenger leaves the vehicle, the distance back to the car depot.

(b) The Sydney taxi rate is $0.75 per kilometre on a ``pickup to drop'' basis. This means the rate is charged for the period the passenger is in the taxi. For most journeys the COMCAR charge would be considerably in excess of that for taxis.
(3) Rates are set to cover the full costs of providing the service and are economically based.

(4) (a), (b) and (c) Approximate per kilometre costs on a ``depot to depot'' basis based on hourly rates charged at ``pickup to drop'' are not available (other than for one category of passenger, judges and other judicial office holders, in Sydney). Factors which make a direct comparison complex include average traffic speeds (which vary throughout the day), likely journeys and traffic conditions to be encountered, distance from depot to pickup point, distance from drop to depot and waiting times etc.

(5) (a) The reason that the Transport and Storage Group tendered on a per kilometre depot-to-depot basis for the NSW State contract for judges and judicial office holders is that the request for tender specified this method. The tendered rate per kilometre on a ``depot to depot'' basis was assessed by the Transport and Storage Group as equivalent to its VIP hourly rate, pickup to drop, for typical journeys for this category of passenger.
(5) (b) The intention is that there should be no significant difference between the rates for work for NSW judges and other judicial office holders and work for Commonwealth Parliamentarians.
